Title: Hurley has set some ambitious environmental goals but there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
Hurley International is owned by Nike Inc.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a low proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic and recycled cotton and recycled polyester. It minimises off-cuts in parts of its manufacturing process and has a strategy in place to reduce waste in a large portion of its supply chain. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions and has made a public commitment to reduce its emissions by >50% by the year 2025. It has not made a commitment to eliminating hazardous chemicals from its supply chain but it complies with a Restricted Substances List guided by the Zero Discharge of Hazardous Chemicals Group (ZDHC). It reports on its water usage and wastewater management and implements water reduction initiatives. It is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition; however its chemicals policy has attracted criticism from Greenpeace Detox Catwalk.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It may publicly list some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.
Hurley International is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Title: Gymshark is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Gymshark's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It uses recycled packing. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it has set a greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. It complies with REACH restricted substance list to minimise some hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It provides a full list of its suppliers from the final stage of production. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It states that its entire product range is vegan.
Gymshark is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: May 2020

Title: Koral is high fashion activewear for highly active lives.
Description:
KORAL's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the USA, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
KORAL is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: April 2020

Title: ASOS is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
ASOS's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it has set an absolute target. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in most of its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Almost none of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses some policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. It has committed to eliminating some animal products by a set date.
ASOS is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Title: Innovative outdoor products and experiences that fund sustainable poverty relief, move people to do good, and inspire adventure.
Description:
Cotopaxi's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions. There is no evidence it avoids chromium and other chemicals in the leather tanning process. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It audits some of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin or angora.
Cotopaxi is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: November 2019

Title: Classiques Entier has made a public commitment to reduce its carbon emissions but there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
Classiques Entier is owned by Nordstrom Inc.
Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. It is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition and the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP). It has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear target. It has adopted the American Apparel and Footwear Association’s Restricted Substance List. However it has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Supplier Code of Conduct based off the ILO Conventions, Fair labor Standards Act and UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human rights. It is part of the Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety and Business for Social Responsibility (BSR) but it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It traces suppliers in part of its supply chain and some of its supply chain is independently audited. However there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses wool, leather, angora and cashmere without stating its sources. It does not use fur, down feather or other exotic animal skin or hair.
Classiques Entier is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Gap has good policies to manage water use in its supply chain but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Gap is owned by Gap, Inc.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. It received an 'A' in the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) water security questionnaire. It demonstrates leadership in managing water use in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses inadequate policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a basic formal policy to protect animal welfare. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, down or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Gap is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Title: KMART Australia is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals or reduce its water impact in its supply chain
Description:
KMART Australia is owned by Wesfarmers.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials and there is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater managementin its supply chain. It is taking steps to implement a recycling program and has set a target to reduce non-textile waste in stores. It reports and measures its direct and indirect greenhouse gas emissions and has set an energy efficiency target to reduce average store energy use (and therefore greenhouse gas emissions) by at least 20% by 2020, although it does not have a target to reduce emissions in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO principles. It traces most of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It publicly lists some of its suppliers along with their addresses. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and down feather without specifying its sources. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin or hair.
KMART Australia is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Title: New Balance is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
New Balance's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has a policy to prevent deforestation in the supply chain. It uses some renewable energy in its supply chain to reduce its climate impact.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by FLA Workplace Code of Conduct including all of the final stage of production. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses some policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has an animal welfare policy. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
New Balance is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Title: Macpac does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Macpac's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it has a repair and reuse program in place. It does not have adequate policies on energy use and carbon emissions. It has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals from its supply chain however it complies with a Restricted Substances List. It has taken no action to eliminate or minimise environmental pollution of chromium and other chemicals from leather tanning processes and it does not mention its policy regarding solvent-based chemicals in its shoe manufacturing. It does not measure or report on water usage and wastewater management and it has no water reduction initiatives or policies.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. However it only audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain and it has no worker empowerment initiatives. It has also made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources. It uses down and feathers but 100% is accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin or hair.
Macpac is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: August 2017

Title: Hunkemöller does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Hunkemöller's environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It is a member of the Business Social Compliance Initiative Code of Conduct - BSCI. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs.There is no evidence of listing names or addresses for any of its suppliers
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, wool, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair and angora. However it uses down and silk.
Hunkemöller is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2018

Title: Arc’teryx is not taking adequate steps to reduce textile waste in its supply chain.
Description:
Arc’teryx is owned by Amer Sports.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives. It complies with its own Restricted Substances List. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain but does not specify what percentage. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final and second stages of production.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses leather.
Arc’teryx is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: September 2019

Title: Lisa Marie Fernandez is a global luxury lifestyle brand that encompasses swimwear, destination wear and active wear.
Description:
Lisa Marie Fernandez's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the USA, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
Lisa Marie Fernandez is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: December 2019

Title: Silou London is a luxury athleisure brand, designed for the female SILOU-ette.
Description:
Silou's environment rating is 'not good enough'. Its products are Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions. There is no evidence it has taken any meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Lithuania, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It visits its suppliers.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Silou is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: July 2019

Title: Knix is an intimates brand that is designed for everyday women by women for every stage of life.
Description:
Knix's environment rating is 'not good enough'. Its products are Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its factories are fully certified by Social Accountability International - SA8000 and Worldwide Responsible Accredited Production - WRAP. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Knix is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Ideology is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
Ideology is owned by Macy’s, Inc.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It offers a recycle program but does not report on the percentage of production recovered. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste across its supply chain. It does not measure or report on its direct and indirect emissions however it has made a public commitment to reduce its emissions by another 2% per year in 2017 and 2018. It claims to be taking steps to meet its carbon reduction target but is not fully transparent about how. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. It claims to have water reduction targets and initiatives but these are not public. It is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a supplier Code of Conduct based on the Ethical Trading Initiative Code but it is unclear if it applies to all of its supply chain. There is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It does not adequately trace suppliers in its supply chain or publicly share a list of its suppliers, however some of its supply chain is independently audited and it uses unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.
Ideology is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Lands' End has not set specifc targets to reduce carbon emissions or water usage and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
Lands' End environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it does offer a recycle program and reports on the percentage of production recovered. It does not measure or report on its direct and indirect emissions, or that of its supply chain although it has taken meaningful action to reduce energy and emissions in its operations. It does not measure or report on water usage and wastewater management.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a robust Supplier Code of Conduct that applies across the entire supply chain but there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear to what extent and some of its supply chain is independently audited. It does not appear to use unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses wool and leather without stating it sources, and it uses down feather but 100% is accredited by the [RDS}. It does not use fur, angora, or exotic animal skin or hair.
Lands' End is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: December 2017

Title: Big W does not have adequate policies on greenhouse gas emissions and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
Big W is owned by Woolworths Ltd.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials and it does not offer any warranties or repair programs on its products but it is taking steps to minimise the use of packaging. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions and has set an absolute greenhouse gas target. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. It has water reduction initiatives but has not set any specific reduction targets.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It may publicly list some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period and has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses wool and leather without specifying its sources. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair.
Big W is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: November 2017

Title: Sonoma is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals or trace suppliers in its supply chain
Description:
Sonoma is owned by Kohl’s Corporation.
Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste across its supply chain. However it does not use eco-friendly materials. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions and has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions, but it has not yet set a clear time bound carbon reduction target. It complies with a Restricted Substances List guided by the Higg Index but it has not made a commitment to eliminating hazardous chemicals. It has water reduction initiatives but has not set any specific reduction targets. It is a founding member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It covers most workers’ rights principles in its Code of Conduct. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse, but it is a founding member of the Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety. It pays a wage in accordance with local laws but not in definition of a living wage. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear to what extent. Some of its supply chain is independently audited and around 50% of its audits are unannounced.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather and wool from unspecified sources. It does not use down, angora or exotic animal skin or hair. In 2014, some of its faux fur products were found to be made of real fur.
Sonoma is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Everlast does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Everlast is owned by Designworks.
Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain and has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use fur, angora but it uses wool and leather without specifying sources.
Everlast is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: May 2017

Title: Regatta's environment policies do not extend far enough down the supply chain
Description:
Regatta is owned by Myers Holdings LimitedIts environment rating is not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it creates high-quality, long-lasting products and it is taking steps to reduce waste in its direct operations. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions but does not do so for its entire supply chain and it has made no commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but it has set a target to reduce its energy intensity. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain or has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management.
Its labour rating is not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces some of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It likely does not publicly list its suppliers but it does ensure that none or only a small amount of subcontracting occurs. It audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives and has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is it's a start'. It uses wool and leather without stating its sources. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair.
Regatta is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: December 2017

Title: Debenhams is not taking adequate steps to minimise textile waste in its supply chain.
Description:
Debenhams's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in part of its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and down. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Debenhams is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: La Senza does not use eco-friendly materials or ensure payment of a living wage across its supply chain
Description:
La Senza is owned by L Brands.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not have adequate policies and initiatives for resource management and disposal. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions, but not for its entire supply chain and it does not use any widely accepted tools to guide measurement and reporting. It has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear time bound target. It has set a deadline for the elimination of hazardous chemicals by 2020 and it complies with a Restricted Substances List. It also has water reduction initiatives but has not set a specific reduction target. It participates in the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP).
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received a good score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. However it traces only one stage of its supply chain, it likely does not publicly list its suppliers and it does not guarantee that subcontracting does not occur in any of its supply chain. It audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period and it has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.
La Senza is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: August 2017

Title: Hush is a UK based brand promoting a laid-back style.
Description:
Hush's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has adopted the Ethical Trading Initiative - ETI base Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.
Hush is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Alala is luxury women's activewear brand with a sophisticated downtown attitude that was created for precisely the way we live today
Description:
Alala's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its labour policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on its workers.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, wool, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses down.
Alala is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2020

Title: Grand Slam does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Grand Slam is owned by Perry Ellis.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It covers most workers' rights principles in its Code of Conduct however it is unclear if this applies to all of its supply chain. There is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. Some of its supply chain is independently audited however it is unclear if it traces its suppliers in all of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use, leather, wool, angora, fur, down or exotic animal skin or hair.
Grand Slam is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Chiara Ferragni offers playful and distinctive collections of clothing, shoes and accessories.
Description:
Chiara Ferragni's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, down and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin or angora.
Chiara Ferragni is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Maurices does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Maurices is owned by Ascena Retail Group Inc.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It is taking steps to create a robust Supplier Code of Conduct but this only applies across the final stage of production. It does not address worker empowerment and it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It does not adequately trace suppliers in its supply chain or publicly share a list of its suppliers. There is no evidence that it provides a living wage for it workers. It self-audits some of its supply chain and it uses unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, angora or any exotic animal skin or hair. It uses leather and wool without specifying its sources.
Maurices is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Fjällräven has not set specific targets to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions
Description:
Fjällräven is owned by Fenix Outdoor AB.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. There is no evidence of a current greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. It fully complies with REACH. There is no evidence of a current water target or goal.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. It does not disclose whether it pays a living wage at any stage of the supply chain. There is no evidence that it traces any of its supply chain. There is no evidence of auditing any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair and angora. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. However it uses leather and down.
Fjällräven is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2018

Title: Founded by Simon Mottram in London in 2004, Rapha makes the world's finest cycling clothing, offering redefined comfort, performance, and style for all levels of cyclists.
Description:
Rapha's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. It offers free repairs for its products. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It states it has a Code of Conduct but does not publicly share it. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state what percentage
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses down certified by the Responsible Down Standard. It uses leather and wool.
Rapha is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Aerie is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Aerie is owned by AEO Inc.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 11-20% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes some information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not publish a list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur, down, or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Aerie is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Dr. Scholls Shoes does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Dr. Scholls Shoes is owned by Caleres Inc.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It covers most workers' rights principles in its code of conduct. It uses unannounced audits with new suppliers but it only conducts follow up audits if faults occur. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It pays a wage in accordance with local laws but not the definition of a living wage. It traces its suppliers in the final stage of production but does not publicly share a list of suppliers.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal hair and skin. However it uses leather and wool without stating its sources.
Dr. Scholls Shoes is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Dunlop does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Dunlop is owned by Designworks.
Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain and has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather without specifying sources.
Dunlop is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: May 2017

Title: Under Armour is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.

Title: Freya Lingerie does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental and labor policies
Description:
Freya Lingerie is owned by Wacoal Holdings.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not have adequate policies and initiatives for resource management and disposal. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions and has made a public commitment to reduce its emissions by 25% by the year 2020. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain or reduce water usage and waste.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. A large percentage of products are manufactured in-house. It addresses some workers rights in a formal statement but does not mention a Code of Conduct. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its labor policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on its labor practices.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labor scores only.
Freya Lingerie and Swimwear is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

It does not disclose adequate policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Nordstrom is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Moncler uses fur.
Description:
Moncler's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It uses some renewable energy in its direct operations to reduce its climate impact but there is no evidence it uses renewable energy in its supply chain. It complies with REACH restricted substance list to minimise some hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Most of its final stage of production is undertaken in Romania, a high risk country for labour abuse. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It has worker empowerment initiatives in its supply chain such as meetings with collective bargaining groups. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It audits its supply chain including most of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses fur, leather, wool, exotic animal hair and angora. It uses down certified by the Down Integrity System and Traceability Protocol. It does not use exotic animal skin.
Moncler is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: April 2020

Title: boohoo is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
boohoo's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. It measures and reports greenhouse gas emissions from its direct operation but not its supply chain. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'very poor'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Sedex Members Ethical Trade Audit - SMETA Best Practice Guidance in the final stage of production. It received a score of 0-10% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes zero or very limited information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not disclose any information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather and wool. It does not use fur, down, angora, exotic animal skin or hair. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production.
boohoo is rated 'We avoid' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Title: River Island does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies.
Description:

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 21-30% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, angora, exotic animal skin or down. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production.
River Island is rated 'We avoid' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Superdry is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Superdry is owned by SuperGroup plc.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It uses some renewable energy in its direct operations to reduce its climate impact but not its supply chain. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'very poor'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 11-20% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes some information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not publish a list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose adequate policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with [Five Freedoms]. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Superdry is rated 'We avoid' overall.

Title: Fendi uses fur, angora and exotic animal products.
Description:
Fendi is owned by LVMH.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. It complies with its own Restricted Substances List but there is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in medium risk countries for labour abuse. It received a score of 21-30% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'very poor'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses fur, down, leather, wool, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair and angora. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Fendi is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Description:
O-Mighty's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. Its final stage of production is manufactured in-house. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but does not state that it's vegan.
O-Mighty is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It states it has a Code of Conduct but does not publicly share it. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. Title: Tuckerman & Co makes premium dress shirts using the finest organic cotton, Italian fabric, and expert New England craftsmanship
Description:
Tuckerman & Co environment rating is 'great'. It is 100% certified by Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton and Oeko-Tex Standard 100. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton to create high-quality, long-lasting products. It uses 100% renewable energy in most of its supply chain and manufactures and supplies to its main market. It does not mention policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management.
Its labour rating is 'great'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the USA, a medium risk country for labour rights. It publishes information on how much it pays its final stage of production employees and that they are unionised. It uses Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton certified cotton, which provides a definition for a living wage. It publicly lists the countries of its suppliers but does not share a list of suppliers. Some of its supply chain is either visited by the brand or audited by Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.
Tuckerman & Co is rated 'Great' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2017

Title: Mayamiko offers contemporary clothing, accessories, jewellery and homeware designed using organic and traditional textiles from Africa, Asia and Italy.
Description:
Mayamiko's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton cotton. It uses renewable energy in its supply chain to reduce its climate impact. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in most of its products. It has a limited production run to minimise textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'great'. It is a member of the WFTO Guarantee System. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It ensures payment of a living wage in the final stage of production. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It traces most of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It is listed by PETA as vegan.
Mayamiko is rated 'Great' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Thunderpants is a New Zealand brand that makes clothing for the whole family, designed to fit and built to last.
Description:
Thunderpants NZ's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton cotton. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in all of its products. It reuses its offcuts to minimise textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'great'. Its products are certified by Fairtrade International - Small Producers Organisations. It sources its final stage of production from New Zealand, a low risk country for labour abuse. It traces all of its supply chain. It ensures payment of a living wage throughout its supply chain.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Thunderpants NZ is rated 'Great' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Its labour rating is 'great'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It monitors health and safety issues through a third party audit of its final stage of production suppliers. It ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It is listed by PETA as vegan.
MUD Jeans is rated 'Great' based on information from our own research.

Its labour rating is 'great'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the USA, a medium risk country for labour rights. It ensures payment of a living wage across its supply chain. It traces all of its supply chain. It audits all of its supply chain.

Title: Make an Impact offers high quality ethical clothing, made from sustainable organic materials with 10% of profits donated to charity
Description:

Almost all of its range uses eco-friendly materials including GOTS-certified cotton, recycled polyester and Tencel to create high-quality, long-lived products. It does not seem to take specific steps to reduce energy use and carbon emissions however its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact. Its use of Oeko-Tex Standard 100 and Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton certified materials also reduces its usage of hazardous chemicals, water usage and wastewater output. It is REACH-compliant.
Its labour rating is 'great'. It is certified by the Fair Wear foundation and states it is committed to eradicating exploitative practices within the textile industry.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.
Make An Impact is rated 'Great' based on our own research.
Last Updated: May 2017

Title: Passion Lilie creates affordable, ethical fashion using traditional techniques to provide dignified employment to artisans in India
Description:
Passion Lilie’s environment rating is 'great'. It uses a proportion of eco-friendly organic cotton and conventional cotton to create high-quality, long-lasting products. It has a robust strategy in place to reduce waste across its entire supply chain by reusing offcuts and minimising the use of packaging. It reduces its energy use by using sunlight to dry fabric throughout the manufacturing process, and reduces its carbon footprint by hand-manufacturing its products. It hand dyes its textiles using natural plant-based dyes to limit its use of hazardous chemicals and it reduces its water use by washing fabric in the river during the manufacturing process.
Its labour rating is 'good'. It is a Fair Trade Federation member and conducts the final stage of production in a WFTO Guarantee System certified factory. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse but works to address those risks through use of fair trade principles. It addresses workers’ rights in a formal statement but does not mention a Code of Conduct. It mentions paying an above average wage, but does not supply any more detail. It traces suppliers in the final and second stages of its supply chain but does not mention suppliers for the first stages of production. It visits its suppliers at the final and second stages of production yearly.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It uses 100% vegan materials.
Passion Lilie is rated 'Great' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

It prints its materials using low impact and non-toxic dyes, thereby reducing its overall environmental impact.
Its labour rating is 'great'. It has been accredited by the Ethical Clothing Australia, and the brand has a social mission to employ and train workers from recent migrant and refugee communities.

Title: Sustainable, organic and Fairtrade clothing helping to economically empower women. Liminal have a wide range of organic cotton basics for men, women and children and specialise in custom print shirts and tote bags.
Description:
Liminal's environmental rating is 'great'. The majority of the brand's products are made from Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton certified cotton. While it does not seem to take specific steps to reduce energy use and carbon emissions, its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact. Its use of Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton certified cotton and dyeing processes limits its use of hazardous chemicals, and reduces the brand's overall water usage.
Its labour rating is 'great'. The majority of Liminal's products are produced by Freeset, a WFTO Guarantee System certified producer. Other garments produced for the brand are made in WFTO Guarantee System, Fair Trade Federation, and Fairtrade International - Small Producers Organisations facilities, and therefore operate under robust Codes of Conduct. The use of WFTO Guarantee System certified facilities guarantees a living wage for their workers. It traces suppliers across its entire supply chain, and has created an interactive traceability map for some of its products. It is a leading advocate for better labour rights, and Freeset is an organisation which is devoted to helping women trapped in situations involving bonded labour and human trafficking.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, angora or leather but uses a small amount of wool in some products without providing information on sourcing.
Liminal is rated Great based on information from own research.

It supports advocacy for better environmental outcomes by raising money for a non-profit devoted to providing education on the sustainable use of natural resources.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the European Union, a medium risk region for labour rights. Its labour rating is 'good'. It is a member of the Fair Wear Foundation. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. Title: WE-AR clothing is designed for existential living, specialising in men and women's yoga and casual wear
Description:
WE-AR's environmental rating is ‘good’. It uses some organic cotton, linen and lyocell but also uses conventional cotton, polyester, acrylic, suede and wool. However, it does set a yearly target to increase the amount of environmentally friendly materials that it uses, which is encouraging. It uses azo-free dyes and tries to use as many plant based dyes as possible. It uses waste reduction methods in its production and upcycles its fabric offcuts to make other products. It also provides a repair scheme if an item is faulty. Finally it has a policy which includes reducing energy and water consumption in its operations
Its labour rating is ‘good’. It produces all of its clothing in Bali, Indonesia, an extreme-risk country for labour rights. However, all items are made in home-workshops and small factories and it has a clear and detailed code of conduct which includes safe and fair working conditions and a living wage policy. WE-AR regularly checks with the workers to see if they are content with their wages and conditions. It is also creating an ethical manufacturing charter for Bali in conjunction with other stakeholders. For its workers based in NZ, it is an accredited living wage employer.
It’s animal rating is ‘it's a start’. It does not use fur or angora, but does use leather without specifying its sources. It also uses wool which comes from non-mulesed sources.
WE-AR is a certified B Corporation and donates $1 of every purchase towards social projects such as an HIV/AIDS outreach program in Bali.
WE-AR is rated ‘Good’ based on our own research.
Last Updated: June 2017

tonlé is rated 'Great' based on information from our own research.

Title: Me to We makes socially conscious accessories and clothing that make an impact to help you do good through everyday choices
Description:
Me to We's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a high proportion of non eco-friendly materials including viscose and elastane. However it is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste by recycling materials and it is reducing its carbon footprint with a carbon offset program. It shares no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals, including no action to eliminate or minimise the environmental pollution of chromium and other chemicals from leather tanning processes. It shares no water reduction initiatives or policies.
Its labour rating is 'great'. It is certified B Corporation. It is a leading advocate for better labour rights and is a social enterprise that exists to provide employment and resources for people from disadvantaged countries. It addresses workers' rights in a formal statement but does not mention a Code of Conduct. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse but attempts to address those risks by paying a living wage at the final stage of production, giving artisans 2.2 times more than what is considered a fair wage by the B Lab. It independently audits some of its supply chain and also traces and publicly shares a list of all suppliers.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use wool, angora, fur, down or exotic animal skin or hair. However it uses leather without stating its sources.
Me to We is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

It makes products by hand to reduce its climate impact. It uses low impact dyes in all of its products. It uses packaging made from recycled materials.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it investigates and reports on safety incidents. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It ensures payment of a living wage to some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It traces some of its supply chain. There is no evidence of auditing any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
Good Krama is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

Title: Stella McCartney has made a public commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions
Description:
Stella McCartney's environment rating is 'good'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled polyester and organic cotton. It has a strategy in place to reduce waste across its entire supply chain. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect greenhouse gas emissions and it has set an approved science-based target to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions. It has set a deadline for the elimination of hazardous chemicals by 2020 and complies with a Restricted Substances List. It has a policy to minimise solvent-based chemicals. It has set water reduction targets and wastewater is treated and discharged properly. It is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition.
Its labor rating is 'it's a start'. It is a member of the Ethical Trading Initiative - ETI and it has adopted the ETI Code of Conduct that includes a living wage definition. It traces suppliers in most of its supply chain. It publicly lists the countries of its suppliers but it does not share a complete list of suppliers. It audits some of its supply chain and it uses unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use leather, down, fur, angora, shearling or exotic animal skins or hairs. It uses wool and cashmere.
Stella McCartney is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2019

Description:

Its labour rating is ‘it’s a start’. Its clothing is made in Portugal, a medium-risk country for labour rights. Its employees receive living wages and health care benefits.

It does not source from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse and it traces suppliers in the final stage of production. It pays a wage in accordance with local laws but not in definition of a living wage.

Untouched World is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: September 2019

Title: P. J. Salvage has taken steps to address environmental issues and does not use any animal products
Description:
P. J. Salvage is owned by Delta Galil Industries.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste in the manufacturing part of its supply chain. However it does not use eco-friendly materials. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions it has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions per product by 5% by 2016. The majority of its products are Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. It implements water reduction initiatives and publicly reports on targets however this only covers in-house manufacturing.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a supplier Code of Conduct based on the FLA Workplace Code of Conduct. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It mentions paying a living wage and supplies an adequate definition but it does not assure payment of a living wage. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear as to what extent. As of 2014, it claimed to have audited 80% of its manufacturing suppliers for human rights screening but it does not appear to use unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.
P. J. Salvage is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Afends is Byron Bay based fashion brand leading the way in organic hemp fashion.
Description:
Afends's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It uses renewable energy in its supply chain to reduce its climate impact. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain. It audits some of its suppliers.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather.
Afends is rated 'Good' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: haikure is a brand that features a contemporary fashion lifestyle for responsible people.
Description:
haikure is owned by CS Jeans.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. There is no it minimises packaging.
Its labour rating is 'good'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. It states it has a Code of Conduct but does not publicly share it. It traces all of its supply chain. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain but does not specify what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather and wool.
haikure is rated 'Good' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Clothing for women, with a selection of limited ranges made from vintage textiles
Description:
Dolores Haze's environmental rating is 'good'. Its produces a large number of products from environmentally friendly materials such as recycled vintage textiles, organic cotton and tencel. It also places an emphasis on the importance of sourcing materials locally to reduce pollution associated with shipping.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start’. It manufactures locally in New York City, USA, a medium-risk country for labour rights. However, greater transparency of labour policies is still needed.
Its animal welfare rating is 'good'. It uses some wool in the manufacturing process without providing information on sourcing. It also uses vegan leather made from polyurethane across a small portion of its product range.
Dolores Haze is rated as 'Good' based on our own research.
Last Updated: November 2016

Title: A shoe and bag brand that owns and operates the world's first Fair Trade Certified factory, based in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
Description:
Olibertés environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. It has its own policy to reduce chromium from its leather tanning processes. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'great'. Its products are Fair Trade USA certified. It sources from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse but it ensures a payment of a living wage to all of its final stage of production. It traces most of its supply. It audits some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start' It does not use wool, fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair. It uses leather.
Oliberté is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: August 2018

Title: Effortless clothing made from custom woven fabrications and made by artisan weavers in India.
Description:
ace&jig's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. It makes products by hand to reduce its climate impact. There is no evidence that it has taken any meaningful action to eliminate hazardous chemicals. It reuses all of its offcuts to minimise textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It traces all of its supply chain. It visits most of its suppliers regularly. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
ace&jig is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2019

Title: Mercado Global creates unique hand-woven bags and homewares that empower indigenous women to overcome poverty & become agents of change in their communities
Description:
Mercado Global's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not provide enough information on its material use and sourcing. However it is in the process of eliminating hazardous chemicals and it limits its carbon emissions by handcrafting its products using traditional and artisanal Mayan methods. It uses leather from TATA International which recycles the chemical chromium from the leather tanning process.
Its labour rating is 'great'. It is a social enterprise that exists to provide employment for women and indigenous artisans in rural Guatemalan communities. It has programs in place to give its artisans access to business training and community-based education programs as well as microloans for technology such as sewing machines and floor looms. It addresses workers' rights and mentions payment of a living wage. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse but attempts to address those risks by tracing suppliers in all of its supply chain. It publishes a complete list of suppliers and audits more than once a year by third party or internal auditors.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather sourced from TATA international, under high environmental standards however there is no mention of animal treatment. It uses wool without stating its sources. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair.
Mercado Global is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It audits some of its suppliers.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It states that its entire product range is vegan.
Wholesome Culture is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its products are manufactured in-house by the owner and a small team. It traces some of its supply chain. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather, wool and silk.

Title: The Fable offers handmade, ethically sourced silk shirts of the highest quality.
Description:
