It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in all of its products. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'good'. Its final stage of production has undergone a Workplace Condition Assessment (WCA). It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse however it ensures payment of a living wage across its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair and angora. However it uses silk.
The Fable is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. However its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' It does not disclose where all of its final stage of production occurs. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain. Some of its supply chain is audited by Worldwide Responsible Accredited Production - WRAP.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, down, wool, leather, exotic animal hair or exotic animal skin. It uses silk.
JEMIMASARA is rated 'It's a start' overall.

Title: Lé BUNS is an Australian eco-friendly collection of luxe organic cotton underwear & sustainable swimwear.
Description:
Lé BUNS's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton cotton. It encourages consumers to reduce their climate impact when using its products. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in all of its products. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It visits its suppliers but does not state how often.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Lé BUNS is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Title: Allison Parris is a New York based brand with eco-friendly & socially conscious collections of evening dresses and gowns. It uses a mix of recycled materials and is made in the USA.
Description:
Allison Parris' environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled PET and organic silks, and a proportion of non eco-friendly materials including conventional cotton. It reduces its carbon footprint by manufacturing close to its main retail outlets. It has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the USA, a medium risk country for labour rights. It addresses workers rights in a formal statement but does not mention a Code of Conduct. It does not adequately trace suppliers in its supply chain or publicly share a list of its suppliers. There is no evidence that it adequately audits its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It uses leather without stating its sources. It does not use fur, wool, down and/or other feathers, angora or exotic animal skin and hair.
Allison Parris is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Title: Issey Miyake uses eco-friendly materials but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers
Description:
132 5. Issey Miyake is owned by MIYAKE DESIGN STUDIO.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Japan, a medium risk region for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. 132 5. Issey Miyake is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Title: C&A uses eco-friendly materials but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
C&A's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton cotton. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. It implements some water reduction initiatives in its supply chain. It has set a deadline to eliminate hazardous chemicals by 2020 but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton including the final, second and first stages of production. It received a score of 61-70% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production, some information about the second and first stages of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain however there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It does not disclose adequate policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of Covid-19.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
C&A is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Title: & other stories publishes detailed information about its suppliers and supply chain policies but it creates short-lived, fast fashion products.
Description:
& Other Stories is owned by Hennes & Mauritz.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It has fast fashion traits such as on trend styles and regular new arrivals. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Almost none of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 71-80% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audit and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production, some information about the second and first stages of production and detailed information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes detailed information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain however there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses some policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.but implementation is uncertain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
& Other Stories is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Title: Angela Roi is a luxury designer vegan handbag brand

It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain but there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and down. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur, exotic animal hair or exotic animal skin. It has committed to eliminating down by a specific date.
G-Star RAW is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Three Graces houses the ultimate vacation wardrobe, featuring irresistible dresses and beachwear.
Description:
Three Graces's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It reuses most of its offcuts to minimise textile waste. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the European Union, a low/medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses silk.
Three Graces is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: May 2020

Title: Bali traces most of its supply chain but does not use eco-friendly materials
Description:
Bali is owned by Hanesbrands Incorporated.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it recycles some off-cuts created during the manufacturing process. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions but does not do so for its entire supply chain and it does not use any widely accepted tools to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions. It has made a public commitment to reduce its carbon emissions by 40% by the year 2020 and it has taken meaningful action on meeting its carbon reduction target. It complies with a Restricted Substances List however it has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals from its supply chain. It measures and reports on water usage and wastewater management and publicly reports on targets.
Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It also traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain however it has very few worker empowerment initiatives. It received a good score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.
Bali is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Last Updated: March 2017

Title: CLOSED is a German brand that produces jeans and other ready-to-wear around the globe.
Description:
CLOSED's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It mostly manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. There is no evidence it minimises the use of solvent-based chemicals in its shoe production. It reduces its water use by using waterless digital printing technology.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It monitors health and safety issues by visiting all of its final stage of production suppliers. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, exotic animal hair and silk. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.
CLOSED is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Faithfull the Brand is a collection of effortless pieces designed to be versatile and easy, made with the modern traveller in mind.
Description:
Faithfull the Brand's environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It makes products by hand to reduce its climate impact. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.
Its labour rating is 'good'. It provides jobs for workers from disadvantaged communities. It traces some of its supply chain. It is unclear whether it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
Faithfull the Brand is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Nicole Bridger is a Canadian fashion line that offers clothing & accessories for women who want to look effortlessly chic while maintaining a commitment to the earth and its people
Description:
Nicole Bridger's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a small proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton and Tencel and a high proportion of non-eco-friendly materials including modal. It manufactures some products locally to reduce its carbon footprint and uses some Bluesign certified fabrics to limit its use of hazardous chemicals. However there is no evidence that it has adequate policies or initiatives on energy use, carbon emissions, water usage and wastewater management.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It addresses workers’ rights in a formal statement but does not mention a Code of Conduct. A large amount of its final stage of production is done in Canada, a low risk country for labour rights. It also sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse but attempts to address those risks through actively seeking suppliers with Fair Trade accreditation. However it does not provide any information on its suppliers or their certifications. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear to what extent. It self-audits the local part of its supply chain but does not mention auditing for the rest of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, down, angora, leather, wool or exotic animal skin or hair. However it uses cashmere and alpaca.
Nicole Bridger is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Noisy may has good policies to audit suppliers but has not set specific targets to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions
Description:
Noisy may is owned by Bestseller.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It is a member of the Better Cotton Initiative. It has fast fashion traits such as on trend styles and regular new arrivals. There is no evidence of a current greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. There is no evidence that it has taken any meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. It has a current qualitative water target or goal.
Its labour rating is 'good'. It is a member of the Ethical Trading Initiative - ETI and has adopted the ETI base code. It is a signatory to the Bangladesh Building and Fire Safety Accord. It has a project to improve wages in a part of its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain including all of its final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin and angora. However it uses exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep.
Noisy may is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2018

Title: Alexander McQueen has good policies to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Alexander McQueen is owned by Kering.
Its environment rating is 'good'. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain and it is on track to meet its target. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. It does not use eco-friendly materials. It reduces chromium and other hazardous chemicals from the leather tanning processes.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Most of its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a robust policy to ensure animal welfare in its supply chain. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur, down or exotic animal skin. It traces most animal products to the first stage of production.
Alexander McQueen is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Nau creates premium apparel that blends technical performance & modern design, crafted from sustainably sourced materials
Description:
Nau is owned by BlackYak.
Nau's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton, Tencel and mechanically recycled polyester to create high-quality, long-lasting products. It does not seem to take specific steps to reduce energy use and carbon emissions, however its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact as well as the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production. It supports advocacy for better environmental outcomes by raising money for organisations who are creating lasting environmental change, including People for Bikes and the Conservation Alliance.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its labour policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on its labour practices.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It uses wool from non-mulesed sheep and alpaca without specifying its sources. It also uses recycled down. It does not use leather, angora, fur or exotic animal skin or hair.
Nau is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: September 2017

Title: Beaton is a collection of linen basics in seasonless silhouettes, released in small collections.
Description:
BEATON's environment rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. It uses a limited production run to minimise textile waste. It is unclear whether is uses low impact non-toxic dyes in its products.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Canada, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses wool.
BEATON is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Description:

It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. It uses recycled packaging. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 51-60% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with [Five Freedoms]. It does not use leather, wool, down, angora, exotic animal skin or exotic animal hair. It uses silk.
Eagle Creek is rated 'it's a start' overall.

Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the USA, a medium risk country for labour rights. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather, wool and silk.
Miranda Bennett Studio is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It ensures payment of a living wage in the final stage of production. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses wool and silk.
Roopa is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

It uses renewable energy in its supply chain to reduce its climate impact. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste in its supply chain. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. There is no evidence it investigates and reports on safety incidents. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain but does not specify what percenatge.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin or angora.
United By Blue is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Description:

There is no evidence that it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence that it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'great'. It has a mission to improve social conditions and empower workers from disadvantaged communities. It ensures payment of a living wage in its final stage of production. It traces most of its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.

Title: Fruit of the Loom has some good labour policies but does not set clear targets for reducing carbon emissions or water usage
Description:
Fruit of the Loom is owned by Fruit of the Loom Inc.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use eco-friendly materials, however it is taking steps to minimise waste and the use of packaging. It uses ISO 14064 and GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear time bound carbon reduction target. It is certified by Oeko-Tex Standard 100. It has water reduction initiatives but has not set any specific reduction targets beyond one supplier location.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report which looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces some of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It likely does not publicly list its suppliers but it does ensure that none or only a small amount of subcontracting occurs. It does not audit any of its traced facilities over a two year time period. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.
Fruit of the Loom is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
Elegantees is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

Title: Volcom has made a public commitment to reduce carbon emissions but there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
Volcom is owned by Kering SA.
Its environment rating is 'good'. It does not use eco-friendly materials however it has a robust strategy in place to reduce waste across its entire supply chain. It has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect greenhouse gas emissions by 50% per unit of revenue by the year 2025 and this target has been approved as a Science-Based Target. It has set a deadline for the elimination of hazardous chemicals by 2020 and complies with a Restricted Substances List. It has a policy to eliminate environmental pollution from the use of chromium and other chemicals in its leather tanning processes and it has a policy to minimise solvent-based chemicals. It implements water reduction initiatives and publicly reports on targets. It is also a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a robust Supplier Code of Conduct which applies across the entire supply chain. However there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces suppliers in all of its supply chain and it publicly lists the countries of its suppliers but it does not share a complete list of suppliers. It self-audits some of its supply chain but it does not appear to use unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and down without stating its sources. It does not use fur, angora, shearling or exotic animal skins or hairs.
Volcom is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Title: A contemporary fashion brand designed in London with simple, functional and architectural aesthetics, handmade in India with traditional craft techniques and sustainable materials.
Description:
This brand provides insufficient relevant information about how it reduces its impact on people, the planet and/or animals. You have a right to know how the products you buy affect the issues you care about.
Missoni is rated 'We avoid' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: October 2019

Title: Gramicci has been the soulful, free spirited, brand of the outdoor industry for over thirty years
Description:
Gramicci's environment rating is 'good'. It creates high-quality, long-lasting products. It uses a proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton certified cotton and hemp, and some non eco-friendly materials such as nylon, spandex and polyester. It does not seem to take specific steps to reduce energy use and carbon emissions, however its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Apart from using Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton certified cotton, it does not publish sufficient relevant information about its labour policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on its labour practices.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.
Gramicci is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Berlin club-inspired unisex clothing made from high fashion deadstock
Description:
GmbH's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It it manufactures all products locally to reduce its carbon footprint. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the European Union, a low/medium risk region for labour rights. It does not have an adequate Supplier Code of Conduct. There is no evidence whether or not it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces suppliers in the final stage of its supply chain but it does not appear to audit or visit any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products.
GmbH is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

It makes products by hand to reduce its climate impact. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it investigates and reports on safety incidents. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain but it does not specify what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin or angora. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses exotic animal hair and peace silk.
BITE is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

It does not mention carbon or energy policies nor specific water reduction initiatives or policies.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the USA, a medium risk country for labour rights. It knows its suppliers at the raw materials stage and publicly lists the countries where the materials originate from. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its labour policies to give a higher rating.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses British and Italian wool and exotic animal hair such as cashmere. It does not use fur, down, leather, angora or exotic animal skin.
UNIFORME is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair and angora. However it uses leather and silk. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep.

Title: Onitsuka Tiger is taking steps to minimize its environmental impact but there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
Onitsuka Tiger is owned by the parent company Asics Corp.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It is an ISO 14001:2004 certified brand. It creates high-quality, long-lasting products but it does not use many eco-friendly materials. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions. It has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear time bound carbon reduction target for all of its supply chain. It complies with a Restricted Substances List and claims to be committed to eliminating hazardous chemicals but has not set a deadline or taken any significant action and it still uses solvent-based chemicals. It implements and publishes water reduction initiatives and publicly reports these targets. It also participates in the Higg Index and Sustainable Apparel Coalition.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a robust Supplier Code of Conduct that applies across its final stage of production. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse and pays a wage in accordance with local laws but not in definition of a living wage. It traces suppliers in its supply chain, particularly its final stage of production and inputs stage but it is unclear to what extent. It publicly lists the countries of its suppliers however does not share a complete list of suppliers. It self-audits all of its supply chain and is audited once a year by third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing, however it does not appear to use unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, wool, angora, down feather or any exotic animal hairs and skins. However it does use leather without stating its sources.
Onitsuka Tiger is rated 'It's a start' based on the information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Its animal rating is it's a start'. It states that it uses wool from non-mulesed sheep and it uses alpaca. It does not use leather, fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin.

Title: Calvin Klein has made a public commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions but is not taking adequate steps to reduce textile waste in its supply chain.
Description:
Calvin Klein is owned by PVH Group.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Some of its supply chain is certified by FLA Workplace Code of Conduct including all of the final stage of production. It received a score of 51-60% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain but there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with [Five Freedoms]. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Calvin Klein is rated 'It's a start' overall.

Description:

Its labour rating is 'great'. It participates in a robust program to empower workers. It ensures payment of a living wage in its final stage of production. It traces most of its supply chain. Most of its supply chain is either independently audited or visited by the brand.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.
Huaywasi is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: August 2018

Title: Burberry has good policies to monitor suppliers but it uses exotic animal products
Description:
Burberry's environment rating is 'good'. Its tanneries are audited by the Leather Working Group. It is a member of the Better Cotton Initiative. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set a Science-Based target to reduce greenhouse gases in its own operations by 95% by 2022 and reduce emissions in its supply chain by 30% by 2030. It has set a deadline to eliminate hazardous chemicals by 2020. It implements initiatives to reduce water use.
Its labour rating is 'good'. It monitors health and safety issues with an internal procedure. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, exotic animal skin and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use fur or angora.
Burberry is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2019

Title: Vans is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Vans is owned by VF Corporation.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 51-60% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Vans is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Title: Sorel is committed to reduce carbon emissions but does not assure payment of a living wage
Description:
Sorel is owned by the Columbia Sportswear Company.
Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. Around 60% of its textiles are sourced from Bluesign certified mills. The majority of its range uses non eco-friendly materials but it is starting to use more recycled polyester. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste in its manufacturing and operations parts of its supply chain. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions, but only for its North American operations which excludes most of its manufacturing. It has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear time bound carbon reduction target. It has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals, but it complies with a Restricted Substances List. 95% of its leather is sourced from Leather Working Group accredited tanneries, but it does not state their level of certification. It has no water reduction initiatives or policies. It measures and reports on water usage and wastewater management, but only for facilities which it owns. It is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition.
Its labor rating is 'it's a start'. It has a robust Supplier Code of Conduct based on the FLA Workplace Code of Conduct Workplace Code of Conduct. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse but attempts to address those risks through affiliation with the FLA Workplace Code of Conduct and Uzbek Cotton Pledge. It mentions paying a living wage and supplies an adequate definition, however it does not assure its payment. It traces suppliers in its manufacturing and material inputs parts of its supply chain and it has publicly shared a list of suppliers, but it is unclear whether this is complete or not. It audits some of its supply chain once a year by third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing and all of its audits are unannounced.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses animal fur, leather and shearling from unspecified sources. It uses down feather, but 100% of this is accredited by the Responsible Down Standard and it uses wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora or exotic animal hair or skin.
Sorel is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Sheridan has good labour policies but does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Sheridan is owned by Pacific Brands.
Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. There is insufficient relevant information on environmental sustainability to give this brand an appropriate environmental rating. Customers have a right to know how the products they buy impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces all or almost all of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It publicly lists all or a portion of its suppliers along with their addresses and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain. It has very few worker empowerment initiatives, but is making progress towards paying a living wage across some of its supply chain. It has signed the Bangladesh Building and Fire Safety Accord, is a member of the Ethical Trading Initiative - ETI and has pledged to not knowingly source Uzbek cotton for the manufacturing of any of its products.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, angora or leather but uses wool without specifying sources.
Sheridan is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: May 2017

Title: PF Flyers has not set specific targets to reduce carbon emissions or water usage
Description:
PF Flyers is owned by New Balance Athletics, Inc.
Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. It re-uses/recycles off cuts created during the manufacturing process but does not have any other adequate policies or initiatives for resource management and disposal. It has implemented some renewable energy measures and it reports on its direct and indirect emissions but has not set clear emissions reduction targets. It complies with a Restricted Substances List and has policies to minimise solvent-based chemicals but it has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals from its supply chain. It measures and reports on water usage in its US and EU operations but it has not set concrete reduction targets. It is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition and the Leather Working Group.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. However it only audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain and it has very few worker empowerment initiatives. It has also made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain. It has signed the Uzbek Cotton Pledge and is an affiliate of the FLA Workplace Code of Conduct.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources. It does not use fur, down, angora, shearling or exotic animal hair or skin.
PF Flyers is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Levi's has good policies to manage water use in its supply chain but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Levi's is owned by Levi Strauss & Co.
Its environment rating is 'good'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain and it is on track to meet its target. It implements water reduction initiatives throughout its supply chain. It has set a deadline to eliminate hazardous chemicals by 2020 and it is on track to meet its target.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Almost none of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses wool, leather and down. It does not use fur, angora, exotic animal hair or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Levi's is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. AKOIASWIM is rated 'It's a start' overall.

Title: Splendid uses animal products without specifying sources and there is not enough evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
Splendid is owned by Delta Galil Industries.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste in the manufacturing part of its supply chain. However it does not use eco-friendly materials. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions and it has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect emissions per product by 5% by 2016. The majority of its products are Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. It implements water reduction initiatives and publicly reports on targets however this only covers in-house manufacturing.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a supplier Code of Conduct based on the FLA Workplace Code of Conduct. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It mentions paying a living wage and supplies an adequate definition but it does not assure payment of a living wage. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear as to what extent. As of 2014, it claimed to have audited 80% of its manufacturing suppliers for human rights screening but it does not appear to use unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather and wool from unspecified sources, and it uses angora and alpaca. However it does not use fur, down, shearling or exotic animal skin.
Splendid is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Ambra Maddalena is luxe, high quality swimwear brand made from recycled nylon products
Description:
Ambra Maddalena's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. Its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals and water used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it investigates and reports on safety incidents. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
Ambra Maddalena is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: February 2019

Title: American Apparel does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
American Apparel's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton certified cotton in its organic range however this only makes up a small percentage of its products. It re-uses off cuts created during the manufacturing process but does not have adequate policies on energy use and carbon emissions. It does not use any widely accepted tools to guide measurement and reporting, and there is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management.
Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces all or almost all of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It publicly lists all or a portion of its suppliers along with their addresses and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits all or most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses wool and leather without stating sources. It does not use fur, down or exotic animal skin or hair. It does not produce items with angora, however it resells vintage and one-off garments made with angora.
American Apparel is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Title: Gorman is not taking adequate steps to reduce textile waste in its supply chain but has good policies to trace suppliers.

Gorman is owned by Factory X
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it has set a greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO principles. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It lists names for suppliers from its final stage of production. It audits some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It ensures payment of a living wage to some of it supply chain but does not state what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal skin or hair. It uses wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses leather.
Gorman is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Title: Dockers has good policies to manage water use in its supply chain but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Docker's is owned by Levi Strauss & Co.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain and it is on track to meet its target. It implements water reduction initiatives throughout its supply chain. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Almost none of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with [Five Freedoms] It uses wool and leather. It does not use fur, down, angora, exotic animal hair or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Dockers is rated 'It's a start' overall.

It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces all or almost all of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials.
