Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather and silk.
Zeus+Dione is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: February 2019

Title: Ninety Percent is a premium womenswear brand that curates clothes for the world we want.
Description:
Ninety Percent's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including GOTS cotton. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It ensures payment of a living wage to some of it supply chain but does not specify what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses wool.
Ninety Percent is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: September 2020

Title: Maiyet is a modern, luxury fashion brand for women that partners with global artisans to incorporate exquisitely handcrafted details into its collections
Description:
Maiyet's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It acknowledges the importance of sustainably sourced materials however it does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'good'. It works with a range of artisans from many different countries and has partnered with Nest, an independent not-for-profit organisation that trains and develops artisan businesses. It has good worker empowerment initiatives across some of its supply chain. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse but attempts to address those risks through the Positive Luxury's 'butterfly mark' which states that the brand takes into account a range of labour policies and initiatives such as having no forced labour and equal employment. It also mentions payment of a fair wage but does not define this. It traces suppliers in its supply chain however there is no evidence that it adequately audits its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources. It also uses hair from exotic animals such cashmere, mohair and alpaca. However it has worked with the nomadic goat herders of Outer Mongolia to create FAIR, the world's first ethically sourced and environmentally sustainable cashmere yarn in the world.
Maiyet is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Bik Bok has good policies to audit suppliers in its supply chain but has not set specific targets to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions
Description:
Bik Bok is owned by Varner-Gruppen.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It is a member of the Better Cotton Initiative. It has fast fashion traits such as on trend styles and regular new arrivals. There is no evidence of a current greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. There is no evidence of avoiding chromium and other chemicals in the leather tanning process. Its wastewater is treated and discharged properly.
Its labour rating is 'good'. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse but it has a project to improve wages in a part of its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. All of final stage of production is audited.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin and angora. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. However it uses leather and exotic animal hair.
Bik Bok is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2018

Title: Viktoria & Woods was established in 2004 by Margie Woods, with a simple approach to create effortless wardrobe staples with a pared-back modern feel.
Description:
Viktoria and Woods's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Most of its factories are certified by Ethical Clothing Australia. It does not disclose where all its final stage of production occurs. It traces some of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.
Viktoria and Woods is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: September 2020

Title: Bassike is a considered, design-led brand of ready-to-wear, jersey, denim and accessories, made in Australia
Description:
Bassike's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It uses renewable energy in its supply chain to reduce its climate impact. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. It uses recycled packaging.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Most of its final stage of production is undertaken in Australia, a low risk country for labour abuse. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It traces some of its supply chain. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain but does not state what percentage. It visits some of its suppliers.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, exotic animal hair, angora and silk. It does not use fur, down or exotic animal skin.
Bassike is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: May 2019

Title: Absurdly soft clothes designed in San Francisco and enjoyed by all.
Description:
Marine Layer's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled cotton. It reuses most of its offcuts to minimise textile waste. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It monitors health and safety issues with an internal procedure. It does not disclose where all of its final stage of production occurs. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.
Marine Layer is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: November 2019

Title: Zalando Essentials has good policies to audit suppliers but is not taking adequate steps to manage water use in its supply chain
Description:
Zalando Essentials is owned by Zalando SE.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It is a member of the Better Cotton Initiative. There is no evidence that it minimises textile waste. It has set a greenhouse gas emissions intensity target but it does not specify whether it relates to its direct operations or its supply chain. It fully complies with REACH. There is no evidence that it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It does not mention payment of a living wage. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It audits the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin and angora. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses exotic animal hair.
Zalando Essentials is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2018

Title: Ekoyg is a French brand that promotes ecology, respect and trust sharing timeless and chic fashion since 2003.
Description:
Ekoyg's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton cotton. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in all of its products. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it investigates and reports on safety incidents. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It traces all of its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, exotic animal hair and silk. It uses wool certified by the Responsible Wool Standard. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.
Ekoyg is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Intermix uses animal products without specifying its sources
Description:
Intermix is owned by Gap, Inc.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions and has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions by 50% by 2020. It is taking steps to fully comply with a Restricted Substances List by 2020 but it has taken no action to eliminate or minimise the environmental pollution of chromium and other chemicals from leather tanning processes. It implements water reduction initiatives and publicly reports on targets. It is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report which looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It also traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. However it only audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain and it has minimal worker empowerment initiatives. It received a good score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain. It is a member of the Ethical Trading Initiative - ETI.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and down without stating its sources. It recently transitioned to a fur-free policy but it still makes products with angora, cashmere, mohair, alpaca and shearling.
Intermix is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: June 2017

Title: Spalding has set some good labour standards but is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals or reduce water usage
Description:
Spalding is owned by Fruit of the Loom Inc.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It is taking steps to reduce waste in a large portion of its supply chain and minimise the use of packaging. However it does not use eco-friendly materials. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting but it has made no commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives in place to minimise hazardous chemicals in its supply chain or reduce water usage, despite reporting some water consumption has been reduced.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It may publicly list some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage. It has very few worker empowerment initiatives and it has made little to no progress towards ensuring payment of a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.
Spalding is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Title: Crossroads does not use animal products but has inadequate policies on sustainability
Description:
Crossroads is owned by Specialty Fashion Group.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environment policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It may publicly list some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage. It is a signatory of the Bangladesh Building and Fire Safety Accord.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not any animal products.
Crossroads is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Title: Vanity Fair has some good labour policies but does not set clear targets for reducing carbon emissions or water usage
Description:
Vanity Fair is owned by Fruit of the Loom Inc.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use eco-friendly materials, however it is taking steps to minimise waste and the use of packaging. It uses ISO 14064 and GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear time bound carbon reduction target. It is certified by Oeko-Tex Standard 100. It has water reduction initiatives but has not set any specific reduction targets beyond one supplier location.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces some of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It likely does not publicly list its suppliers but it does ensure that none or only a small amount of subcontracting occurs. It does not audit any of its traced facilities over a two year time period. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.
Vanity Fair is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Title: Millers does not use any animal products but has inadequate policies on sustainability
Description:
Millers is owned by Specialty Fashion Group.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environment policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It may publicly list some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage. It is a signatory of the Bangladesh Building and Fire Safety Accord.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.
Millers is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Title: Reef has made a public commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Reef is owned by VF Corporation.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 51-60% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with [Five Freedoms]. It uses leather. It does not use angora, wool, exotic animal hair, fur, down or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production.
Reef is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Balenciaga has good policies to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions but uses fur, angora and exotic animal skin.
Description:
Balenciaga is owned by Kering.
Its environment rating is 'good'. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain and it is on track to meet its target. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It reduces chromium and other hazardous chemicals from the leather tanning processes.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Most of its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a robust policy to ensure animal welfare in its supply chain. It uses leather, down, fur, angora, exotic animal hair and exotic animal skin. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It traces most animal products to the first stage of production.
Balenciaga is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Edward Crutchley's eponymous label is a reflection of true contemporary luxury.
Description:
Edward Crutchley's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the UK, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin or angora. It uses wool and exotic animal hair.
Edward Crutchley is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: September 2019

Title: Trenery has good policies to prevent deforestation in its supply chain but is not taking adequate steps to empower workers in its supply chain.
Description:
Trenery is owned by Woolworths Holdings Limited.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic linen. It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. It has set a deadline to eliminate hazardous chemicals but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Sedex Members Ethical Trade Audit - SMETA Best Practice Guidance in the final stage of production. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin. It does not trace most animal products to the first stage of production.
Trenery is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: September 2020

Title: Scotch & Soda does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Scotch & Soda's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not take specific steps to reduce its carbon emissions, waste or water use. It complies with REACH however it does not have adequate policies and initiatives for resource management and disposal.
Its labour rating is 'good'. It is a member of the Business Social Compliance Initiative Code of Conduct - BSCI which allows companies with international supply chains to use a common Code of Conduct to improve labour conditions. It is compliant with the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms which requires its suppliers to address gender discrimination, provide grievance mechanisms, privacy protections and ensure payment of a minimum wage. It audits once a year by third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather, wool and cashmere without stating its sources. It does not use down, angora or exotic animal skin.
Scotch & Soda is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: September 2017

Title: Founded in 1875, SCHIESSER has been offering high-quality, feel-good fashion for everyday life for more than 140 years.
Description:
SCHIESSER is owned by Delta Galil.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. It has set a deadline to eliminate hazardous chemicals by 2020. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in its supply chain. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin or angora. It uses wool and exotic animal hair.
SCHIESSER is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Timeless, easy-to-wear clothing made with natural and organic fabrics.
Description:
Bibico's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton and it creates high-quality, long-lasting products. It does not mention carbon or energy policies, chemicals or water reduction initiatives or policies. However its use of some eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'good'. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse but attempts to address those risks by adopting the World Fair Trade Organization Code of Conduct. It ensures that a large proportion of its suppliers pay a living wage. It traces most of its suppliers in all of its supply chain and most of its supply chain is either independently audited or visited by the brand.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, cashmere and mohair without stating its sources. It does not use angora, exotic animal skin or down.
Bibico is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Title: Ted Baker is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain
Description:
Ted Baker's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It participates in Sustainable Clothing Action Plan and Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP). It uses a small proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton and Tencel®, and a proportion of non eco-friendly materials such as Modal® and bamboo. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste in a small portion of its supply chain. It has made a commitment through Sustainable Clothing Action Plan to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but it has not publicly disclosed this target. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions but does not measure all material emissions in its value chain. It has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals and there is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It has a Supplier Code of Conduct based on the Ethical Trading Initiative - ETI. It is taking steps to ensure that a large proportion of its suppliers pay a living wage and it is creating a methodology to calculate a living wage consistent with International Labour Organisation definitions. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear to what extent. It self-audits all of its supply chain and some of its supply chain is independently audited. However it does not appear to use unannounced audits and it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources and uses down feather that does not hold any accreditations. It does not use fur, angora, shearling or any exotic animal hairs or skins.
Ted Baker is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on the information from our own research.
Last Updated: September 2017

Title: Croft & Barrow is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Croft & Barrow is owned by Kohl's.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It is a member of the Better Cotton Initiative. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gases in its own operations by 50% by 2025 but it has not set a supply chain target. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in its supply chain. There is no evidence it avoids chromium and other chemicals in the leather tanning process.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather and wool.
Croft & Barrow is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: December 2019

Title: Champion is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Champion is owned by Hanesbrands.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. It reuses some of its offcuts to minimise textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by FLA Workplace Code of Conduct in the final stage of production. It received a score of 31-40% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It likely publishes a list of suppliers in the final stage of production but not the second stage. It may be publishing limited information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies or safeguards to protect workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not suppliers.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has an animal welfare policy. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Champion is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Big Bud Press is an LA based label specializing in size inclusive, unisex everyday goods, priding themselves on ethical and local manufacturing practices.
Description:
Big Bud Press's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the USA, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
Big Bud Press is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: April 2020

Title: Multi disciplinary design studio based in London, creating garments, objects and printed matter.
Description:
Samuel Gui Yang's environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its products are manufactured in-house by the owner and a small team. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin or angora. It uses wool and exotic animal hair.
Samuel Gui Yang is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Apt. 9 is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Apt. 9 is owned by Kohl's.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It is a member of the Better Cotton Initiative. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gases in its own operations by 50% by 2025 but it has not set a supply chain target. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in its supply chain. There is no evidence it avoids chromium and other chemicals in the leather tanning process.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. Title: Bershka is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Bershka is owned by Inditex.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. It uses recycled packaging. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Half of its final stage of production is undertaken in Spain, a medium risk country for labour abuse. It received a score of 51-60% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. Title: Old Navy has good policies to manage water use in its supply chain but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.

It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. It received an 'A' in the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) water security questionnaire. It demonstrates leadership in managing water use in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses inadequate policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a basic formal policy to protect animal welfare. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Old Navy is rated 'It's a start' overall.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use leather, fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair. It uses wool and silk.
TAHLO is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: August 2018

Title: Hema has not set specific targets to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions
Description:
Hema's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It is a member of the Better Cotton Initiative. There is no evidence that it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence of a current greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. There is no evidence of a current water target or goal.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It is a member of the Business Social Compliance Initiative Code of Conduct - BSCI. It monitors health and safety issues through a third party audit of its final stage of production suppliers. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. There is no evidence of listing names or addresses for any of its suppliers
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair and angora. However it uses leather. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep.
Hema is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2018

Title: Pull&Bear is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Pull&Bear is owned by Inditex.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. It uses recycled packaging. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Half of its final stage of production is undertaken in Spain, a medium risk country for labour abuse. It received a score of 51-60% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses some policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather, down and exotic animal hair.It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Pull&Bear is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Title: HEIMAT ATLANTICA offers handmade bags, accessories and ready-to-wear in unique, handcrafted collections.
Description:
HEIMAT ATLANTICA's environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the European Union, a low/medium risk region for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather.
HEIMAT ATLANTICA is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

Title: Le kasha an elegant wardrobe for the modern traveller using using natural fabrics like silk, cashmere and linen.
Description:
Le Kasha's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including linen. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It visits its suppliers regularly.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, wool, down, exotic animal skin or angora. It uses exotic animal hair and silk.
Le Kasha is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: American Rag is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
American Rag is owned by Macy’s, Inc.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It offers a recycle program but does not report on the percentage of production recovered. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste across its supply chain. It does not measure or report on its direct and indirect emissions however it has made a public commitment to reduce its emissions by another 2% per year in 2017 and 2018. It claims to be taking steps to meet its carbon reduction target but is not fully transparent about how. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. It claims to have water reduction targets and initiatives but these are not public. It is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a supplier Code of Conduct based on the Ethical Trading Initiative Code but it is unclear if it applies to all of its supply chain. There is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It does not adequately trace suppliers in its supply chain or publicly share a list of its suppliers, however some of its supply chain is independently audited and it uses unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.
American Rag is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: A Peace Treaty produces custom handmade pieces which embrace rich color and print, are lively and bold, soft and luxurious
Description:
A Peace Treaty's environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has taken any meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives. It makes products by hand to reduce its climate impact. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It has a mission to improve social conditions. It traces some of its supply chain. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, exotic animal hair and silk. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.
A Peace Treaty is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: February 2019

Title: GANNI uses eco-friendly materials but does not adequately empower workers across its supply chain through collective bargaining or effective complaints processes.
Description:
GANNI's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton cotton. There is no evidence it engages with suppliers on water issues. It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gases by 30% per kg of clothing by 2023 but is has not set an absolute target. It recycles some of its deadstock materials.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It traces some of its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain but does not specify what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, down, exotic animal hair and silk. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin or angora.
GANNI is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: April 2020

Title: Sanuk is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
Sanuk is owned by Deckers Outdoor Corporation (Deckers Brands)
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not have adequate policies and initiatives for resource management and disposal. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions, and has made a public commitment to reduce its Scope 3 emissions by 4 % during 2017. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. However it uses a REACH compliant Restricted Substances List and 98% of its leather is sourced from Leather Working Group certified tanneries. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management for the majority of its supply chain.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It covers most workers' rights principles in its Code of Conduct but it is unclear if it applies to all of its supply chain. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces its manufacturing suppliers and it has publicly shared a complete list of its factories with addresses. It conducts audits once a year using third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing and uses unannounced audits, however it does not audit all of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses wool from non-mulesed sheep and is a member of the Responsible Wool Standard. It does not use down and feathers, or shearling in its products, and it has policies prohibiting the use of fur, angora, and exotic animal skin. However it uses leather without stating its sources.
Sanuk is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Jacob Cohën's luxury denim brand is known for its comfortable, high-quality fabrics paired with exclusive elegance.
Description:
Jacob Cohën's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in some of its products. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, exotic animal hair and angora. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.
Jacob Cohën is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: November 2019

Title: Glassons does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Glassons' environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environment policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces all or almost all of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It publicly lists all or a portion of its suppliers along with their addresses and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain. It has very few worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use leather, angora, fur, down or exotic animal skin or hair. However it uses wool without specifying its sources.
Glassons is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Title: Marcs is not taking adequate steps to reduce textile waste in its supply chain.
Description:
Marcs is owned by Myers Holdings Limited.
Its environment rating is not 'good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it creates high-quality, long-lasting products. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions but not its entire supply chain. It has made no commitment to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions but it has set a target to reduce its energy intensity. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. Very few of its facilities have worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It audits some of its traced facilities. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO principles however it has made little to no progress towards ensuring payment of a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use angora, fur, down or exotic animal skin or hair. It uses wool and leather.
Marcs is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Piper's environment policies do not extend far enough down the supply chain
Description:
Piper is owned by Myers Holdings LimitedIts environment rating is not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it creates high-quality, long-lasting products and it is taking steps to reduce waste in its direct operations. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions but does not do so for its entire supply chain and it has made no commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but it has set a target to reduce its energy intensity. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain or has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management.
Its labour rating is not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces some of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It likely does not publicly list its suppliers but it does ensure that none or only a small amount of subcontracting occurs. It audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives and has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is it's a start'. It uses wool and leather without stating its sources. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair. Piper is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not have adequate policies and initiatives for resource management and disposal. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions and has made a public commitment to reduce its Scope 3 emissions by 4 % during 2017. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. However it uses a REACH compliant Restricted Substances List and 98% of its leather is sourced from Leather Working Group certified tanneries. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management for the majority of its supply chain.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It covers most workers' rights principles in its Code of Conduct but it is unsure if it applies to all of its supply chain. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces its manufacturing suppliers and it has publicly shared a complete list of its factories with addresses. It conducts audits once a year using third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing and uses unannounced audits, however it does not audit all of its supply chain.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labor scores only.
Hoka One One is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the European Union, a low/medium risk region for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, exotic animal hair and silk. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.

Title: Club Monaco is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Club Monaco is owned by Ralph Lauren Corporation.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in most of its supply chain. It uses some recycled packaging.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 21-30% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with [Five Freedoms]. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard or [TDS]. It does not use angora, exotic animal skin or fur. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Club Monaco is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: David Jones is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.

It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces most animal products to the first stage of production.
David Jones is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

Title: Suzanne Grae does not provide sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Suzanne Grae is owned by the Sussan Group.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environment policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period however it has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It received a fairly good score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, angora or exotic animal skin or hair. It uses wool without specifying its sources.
Suzanne Grae is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

Title: Bonds is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Bonds is owned by Hanesbrands.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. It reuses some of its offcuts to minimise textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by FLA Workplace Code of Conduct in the final stage of production. It received a score of 31-40% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It likely publishes a list of suppliers in the final stage of production but not the second stage. It may be publishing limited information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies or safeguards to protect workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not suppliers.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials except for silk so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Bonds is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Rip Curl does not communicate anything specific on its environmental policies and practices
Description:
Rip Curl's environmental rating is 'not good enough'. It has donated money to a number of environmental groups with an emphasis on preserving surf spots and has a 55% ‘eco-friendly fabrics’ label. However, it does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper, you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts and it traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs stage and some or none of its raw material stage. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period, however it has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has also made little to no progress towards paying a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses wool and leather without specifying sources however it does not appear to use fur or angora.
Rip Curl is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Australian Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: May 2017

There is also no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management.
Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces its final and input stages of its supply chain. It does not publicly list all of its suppliers but it ensures that none or only a small amount of subcontracting occurs. It audits all of its traced final stage facilities over a two-year period but does not do so for its entire input stage. It has some worker empowerment initiatives across parts of its supply chain. It has made minimal progress towards ensuring payment of a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources. It also uses fur and exotic animal skins such as crocodile and exotic animal hair such as cashmere. It does not use down or angora.
R.M. Williams is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

Title: Lauren does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental and labor policies
Description:
Lauren is owned by Ralph Lauren Corporation.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It claims to be taking steps to meet its carbon reduction target, but is not fully transparent about how. It measures and reports on its direct emissions only. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It is taking steps to create a robust Supplier Code of Conduct. It traces suppliers in all of its supply chain and tracks the use of temporary or contract workers. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. AIl of its supply chain is independently audited once a year by third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing and it uses unannounced audits. However there is no evidence that it provides a living wage for its workers.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, and down feather without specifying its sources. It also uses the exotic animal hairs cashmere and mohair. It has banned the use of angora and fur in its products.
Lauren is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on the information from our own research.

Title: Ralph Lauren is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Ralph Lauren is owned by Ralph Lauren Corporation.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in most of its supply chain. It uses some recycled packaging.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 21-30% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with [Five Freedoms]. It uses leather, exotic animal hair and exotic animal skin. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard or [TDS]. It does not use angora or fur. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Ralph Lauren is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Forever New does not provide sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Forever New's environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environment policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces all or almost all of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It publicly lists all or a portion of its suppliers along with their addresses and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses wool and leather without specifying its sources. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair.
Forever New is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

Title: Topshop is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Topshop is owned by Arcadia Group.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has fast fashion traits such as on trend styles and regular new arrivals. There is no evidence it has set a greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Sedex Members Ethical Trade Audit - SMETA Best Practice Guidance including all of the final stage of production. It received a score of 31-40% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It likely publishes a list of suppliers in the final stage of production but not the second stage. It may be publishing limited information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Title: Lane Bryant does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:

Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It is taking steps to create a robust Supplier Code of Conduct which only applies across the final stage of production. However it does not address worker empowerment and it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It does not adequately trace suppliers in its supply chain or publicly share a list of its suppliers. There is also no evidence that it provides a living wage for it workers. It self-audits some of its supply chain and it uses unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, angora or any exotic animal skin or hair. However It uses wool without stating its sources.

Title: City Chic does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
City Chic is owned by Specialty Fashion Group. Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environment policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It may publicly list some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage. It is a signatory of the Bangladesh Building and Fire Safety Accord.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use angora or fur but uses wool and leather without specifying sources.
City Chic is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: April 2018

Title: Hugo Boss is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.

There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in most of its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by FLA Workplace Code of Conduct including all of the final stage of production. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses wool, leather, exotic animal hair and down. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
HUGO BOSS is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. However its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it investigates and reports on safety incidents. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Benedetta is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Its labour rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its labour policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on its workers.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.
Envelope1976 is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Charlotte Russe does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has its own Code of Conduct but does not disclose its details. It mainly sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It does not adequately trace suppliers in its supply chain or publicly share a list of its suppliers. It conducts audits by third party auditors in the final stage of production however it is unclear how often these occur.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, angora, down or exotic animal fur or skins. However it uses wool without stating its sources.

Title: Just Jeans does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Just Jeans is owned by the Just Group.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. Only some of its facilities have worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It traces some of its supply chain including a portion of the final stage of production although it is unlikely it publicly list its suppliers. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO principles however it has made little to no progress towards ensuring payment of a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal skin or hair. However it uses leather and wool without stating its sources.
Just Jeans is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Staple the Label does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies

Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces some of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials; it likely does not publicly list its suppliers but it ensures that none or only a small amount of subcontracting occurs. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. It has no worker empowerment initiatives in its supply chain and has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, angora, leather, down or exotic animal skin or hair but uses wool without specifying its sources.

Title: Next is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Next is owned by Next PLC.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 31-40% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It likely publishes a list of suppliers in the final stage of production but not the second stage. It may be publishing limited information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Next is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Title: Eddie Bauer does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers most workers' rights however it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse. It uses third party auditing but is unclear how often and which part of the supply chain it audits.

Title: Roots has not set specific targets to reduce carbon emissions or water usage
Description:
