It uses a proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton, recycled cotton, recycled polyesters and natural sustainable fabrics such as hemp and soy. However it does not have adequate policies on energy use and it does not measure or report on its direct and indirect carbon emissions. It uses vegetable tanning for some of its leather range but it has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals and does not mention its policy regarding solvent-based chemicals in its shoe manufacturing. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management. It supports advocacy for better environmental outcomes by raising money for 'The Stop Global Warming Fund'.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has its own Supplier Code of Conduct which applies across the entire supply chain. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse. It mentions paying a living wage but does not supply its definition or methodology. It uses unannounced, third-party audits and mentions auditing subcontractors however it is unclear how often these occur.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, shearling and down with some down being certified by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use fur, angora or other exotic animal skin or hair.
Roots is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Elka Collective does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies

Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. However it audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its supply chain and it has no worker empowerment initiatives. It also received a mixed score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is [anima]. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources. It does not use down, fur, angora or exotic animal hair or skin.

There is no evidence it uses unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, down and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin or angora.
Helly Hansen is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Alaïa is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain.
Description:

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It reduces its climate impact by consuming renewable energy in its direct operations. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain but does not specify what percentage.

Title: Ann Taylor does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Ann Taylor is owned by Ascena Retail Group Inc.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It is taking steps to create a robust Supplier Code of Conduct which only applies across the final stage of production. However it does not address worker empowerment and it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It does not adequately trace suppliers in its supply chain or publicly share a list of its suppliers. There is also no evidence that it provides a living wage for it workers. It self-audits some of its supply chain and it uses unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather without specifying its sources. It states that it uses wool from non-mulesed sheep and it uses shearling skin. It does not use fur, angora, down or other feathers.
Ann Taylor is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Walmart is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Walmart's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence that it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain and it is on track to meet its target.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 21-30% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose adequate policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of Covid-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses wool, leather and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Walmart is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Title: Wrangler is not taking adequate steps to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions.
Description:
Wrangler is owned by Kontoor Brands.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain. It complies with its own Restricted Substances List but there is no evidence that it has taken meaningful action to eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 51-60% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather and wool. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal hair, exotic animal skin or angora. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Wrangler is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain but does not specify what percentage.

Vilebrequin is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. It has no worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It traces some of its supply chain including a proportion of the final stage of production. It audits only a small proportion of its traced facilities. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO principles however it has made little to no progress towards ensuring payment of a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use angora, leather, fur, down or exotic animal skin or hair. It uses wool from non-mulesed sheep.

Title: Ben Sherman falls short on environmental and supply chain transparency

Its labour rating is ‘not good enough’. It has a code of conduct that addresses certain labour rights, while others are excluded. Once again, transparency is an issue.
Its animal welfare rating is ‘not good enough’. It does not use fur but uses angora, wool and leather without specifying sources.
Additionally, it is rated in the worst 50% of brands for both environmental and social issues by Good Guide. Ben Sherman needs to improve in all areas.
Ben Sherman is rated ‘Not Good Enough’ based on information from Good Guide and our own research.

Title: Noni B does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:

Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces some of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It likely does not publicly list its suppliers but it does ensure that none or only a small amount of subcontracting occurs. It audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period and it has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products

Title: Dotti does not provide sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:

Its environment rating is very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.
Its labour rating is not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It also traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. However it has very few worker empowerment initiatives and it received a poor score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use leather, fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair. It uses wool without specifying its sources.

Title: Monsoon is not taking adequate steps to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions.
Description:
Monsoon's environment rating is 'very poor'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has a policy to prevent deforestation in the supply chain. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Sedex Members Ethical Trade Audit - SMETA Best Practice Guidance in the final stage of production. It received a score of 31-40% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It likely publishes a list of suppliers in the final stage of production but not the second stage. It may be publishing limited information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a basic formal policy to protect animal welfare. It uses leather, exotic animal hair and wool. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production.
Monsoon is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Emilio Pucci is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.

It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. It complies with its own Restricted Substances List but there is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in medium risk countries for labour abuse. It received a score of 21-30% in the FTI. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. Emilio Pucci is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

Title: Sussan does not communicate enough about its environmental policies and practices
Description:
Sussan is owned by Sussan Group.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. There is insufficient relevant information on environment sustainability to give this brand an appropriate environment rating. Customers have a right to know how the products they buy impact on the environment. Sussan Group is a signatory to the Australian Packaging Covenant, a voluntary agreement to minimise waste.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces some of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It likely does not publicly list its suppliers but it does ensure that none or only a small amount of subcontracting occurs. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain. It has very few worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair.
Sussan is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

Title: By Malene Birger is not taking adequate steps to manage its greenhouse gas emissions.
Description:
By Malene Birger is owned by IC Group.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions. It fully complies with REACH. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It is a member of the Business Social Compliance Initiative Code of Conduct - BSCI. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain including most of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin or angora.
By Malene Birger is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Mulberry does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Mulberry's environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it investigates and reports on safety incidents. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It sources its final stage of production from countries with high risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair and angora. It does not use fur or down.

Title: PacSun does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
PacSun is owned by Golden Gate Capital. This rating only applies to the brand PacSun and not to the other brands that it sells.
Its environmental rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Supplier Code of Conduct which covers most workers' rights principles. There is no evidence that it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear as to what extent and it does not publicly disclose the countries of its suppliers. Some of its supply chain is independently audited but it is unclear how often. It does not use unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal skin or hair. However it uses leather and wool from unspecified sources.
PacSun is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Cortefiel is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Cortefiel's environment rating is 'not good enough'. it uses few eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. It uses some renewable energy in its direct operations to reduce its climate impact but not its supply chain. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the impacts of microplastics.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Business Social Compliance Initiative Code of Conduct - BSCI in the final stage of production. It received a score of 11-20% in the FTI. It likely publishes some information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not publish a list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses inadequate policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather and wool. It does not use fur, angora, down, exotic animal skin or hair. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production

It uses unannounced audits with new suppliers but it only conducts follow up audits if faults occur. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. Title: TEMT does not provide sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
TEMT is owned by Fast Future Brands.
Its environment rating is very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.
Its labour rating is not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces only one stage of its supply chain, it likely does not publicly list its suppliers and it does not ensure that subcontracting does not occur. It audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its supply chain and has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage.
Its animal rating is Great. It does not use any animal products
TEMT is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: September 2017

Title: Yarra Trail does not provide sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Yarra Trail is owned by the PAS Group.
Its environment rating is very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces all or almost all of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It publicly lists all or a portion of its suppliers along with their addresses and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It also audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain. It has good worker empowerment initiatives but it has made little to no progress towards a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is it's a start'. It uses leather alpaca, cashmere and mohair without specifying its sources. It states that it uses wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, angora or down.
Yarra Trail is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers some of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. There is no evidence that it has any worker empowerment initiatives. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs and it does not mention payment of a living wage. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair.
Aéropostale is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Aritzia is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Aritzia's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including Tencel. There is no evidence that it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 11-20% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes some information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not publish a list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses wool, leather and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Aritzia is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Saucony does not communicate sufficient informaiton about its environmental policies
Description:
Saucony is owned by Wolverine Worldwide Inc.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It shares a summary of its Code of Conduct which covers most workers rights principles including a ban on child labor and forced overtime. Its Supplier Code of Conduct applies across all production partners but it is up to its partners to enforce it with subcontractors. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse and it pays a wage in accordance with local laws but not in definition of a living wage. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear to what extent, and it mentions auditing but it is unclear how often and which part of the supply chain it audits.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources..It does not use fur, angora, cashmere, down feather or other exotic animal skins or hairs.
Saucony is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: KENZO is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:

It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. It complies with its own Restricted Substances List but there is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in medium risk countries for labour abuse. It received a score of 21-30% in the FTI. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. Title: Aldo does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental and labor policies
Description:

However it does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper, you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct but does not disclose its details. It does not state the countries from which it sources production. There is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear to what extent. It mentions auditing but it is unclear how often and which part of the supply chain it audits. It uses unannounced audits and conducts off-site worker interviews.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and shearling without stating its sources. It does not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal skin or hair.
Aldo is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Sam Edelmandoes not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies

Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It covers most workers' rights principles in its code of conduct. Title: Marc Jacobs is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Marc Jacobs is owned by LVMH.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. It complies with its own Restricted Substances List but there is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 21-30% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Marc Jacobs is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

Title: Portmans does not provide sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Portmans is owned by Just Group.
Its environment rating is very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.
Its labour rating is not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It also traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. However it has very few worker empowerment initiatives and it received a poor score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is it's a start'. It uses wool and leather without specifying its sources. It does not use fur down, angora or exotic animal skin or hair.
Portmans is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

Title: Review does not provide sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Review is owned by the PAS Group.
Its environment rating is very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces all or almost all of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It publicly lists all or a portion of its suppliers along with their addresses and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It also audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain. It has good worker empowerment initiatives but it has made little to no progress towards a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is it's a start'. It uses leather without specifying its sources. It states that it uses wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair.
Review is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: September 2017

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, down and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin or angora.

There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.

Title: L.L.Bean is not taking adequate steps to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions.
Description:
L.L. Bean's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the impacts of microplastics. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'very poor'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 0-10% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes zero or very limited information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not disclose any information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather, exotic animal hair and wool. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
L.L. Bean is rated 'We avoid' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Loro Piana is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Loro Piana is owned by LVMH.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. It complies with its own Restricted Substances List but there is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in medium risk countries for labour abuse. It received a score of 21-30% in the FTI. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Loro Piana is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. It complies with its own Restricted Substances List but there is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in medium risk countries for labour abuse. It received a score of 21-30% in the FTI. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses fur, leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use down, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Givenchy is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: September 2020

It does not mention payment of a living wage. There is no evidence of listing countries for any of its suppliers. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state which part and what percentage.

Title: Jacqui E does not provide sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Jacqui E is owned by Just Group.
Its environment rating is very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.
Its labour rating is not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It also traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. However it has very few worker empowerment initiatives and it received a poor score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is it's a start'. It uses leather and wool without specifying its sources. It does not use wool, fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair.
Jacqui E is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

It received the bottom score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It does not trace any of its supply chain, it does not publicly list any of its suppliers and it does not ensure that subcontracting does not occur. It does not audit any of its traced facilities has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is not good enough'. It uses alpaca, angora, leather and wool without stating its sources. It does not use fur or down.
Jump is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: September 2017

Title: Bisley does not provide sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Bisley is owned by Gazal Corporation Limited.
Its environment rating is very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.
Its labour rating is not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received a good score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It does not trace any of its supply chain or publicly list any of its suppliers and it does not ensure that subcontracting does not occur. It does not audit any of its traced facilities over a two year time period and has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.
Bisley is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: September 2017

Title: Celebrating hybridity above all, in shape, color and references, Marine Serre ignores old conceptual boundaries
Description:
Marine Serre's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including upcycled materials. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its labour policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on its workers..
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It does not disclose which animal products it uses.
Marine Serre is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2019

Title: Skechers is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Skechers' environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. It minimises packaging. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'very poor'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 0-10% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes zero or very limited information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not disclose any information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather and wool. It does not use fur, down, angora, exotic animal skin or hair. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production.
Skechers is rated 'We avoid' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Ermanno Scervino uses fur and exotic animal products.
Description:
Ermanno Scervino's environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, fur, wool, down and exotic animal hair. It does not use exotic animal skin or angora.
Ermanno Scervino is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Roxy does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental and labour policies.
Description:
Roxy is owned by Boardriders.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'very poor'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 0-10% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes zero or very limited information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not disclose any information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. Title: Prada is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Prada is owned by the Prada Group.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It complies with its own Restricted Substances List but there is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Most of its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. It received a score of 11-20% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes some information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not publish a list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose adequate policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'very poor'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather, wool, down, angora, exotic animal skin and exotic animal hair. It has committed to eliminating fur.
Prada is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Description:

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.

Title: Denim luxury designed to make you shine.
Description:
The Blue Suit's environment rating is 'great'. It is fully certified by Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton. It reduces its climate impact by manufacturing locally. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in all of its products.
Its labour rating is 'great'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the USA a medium risk region for labour rights. It ensures payment of a living wage across all of its supply chain. It traces all of its supply chain
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
The Blue Suit is rated 'Great' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: November 2018

Title: Outland Denim crafts premium denim jeans and offers sustainable employment and training opportunities to women who have experienced exploitation.
Description:
Outland Denim's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in all of its products. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'great'. It is a social enterprise that assists in creating employment opportunities for women who have been trafficked in Cambodia. It traces all of its supply chain. It ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather.
Outland Denim is rated 'Great' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: August 2019

Title: Swedish Stockings creates good quality black and patterned stockings, knee highs, tights, socks and pantyhose for all women.
Description:
Swedish Stockings's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It uses renewable energy in its supply chain to reduce its climate impact. It reuses its offcuts to minimise textile waste. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'good'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. Its second stage of production is certified by Social Accountability International - SA8000. It traces most of its supply chain. It is unclear whether it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, wool, down, exotic animal skin or angora. It uses exotic animal hair.
Swedish Stockings is rated 'Great' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Deadwood makes recycled leather jackets, a celebration of ageless rebellion & free-spiritedness
Description:
DEADWOOD's environment rating is 'great'. It uses recycled leather in all its jackets and organic cotton in its beanies. It recycles off-cuts created during the manufacturing process. Its use of eco-friendly materials means it reduces its climate impact, uses fewer chemicals and less water and wastewater
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production occurs in its atelier in Thailand. It addresses workers' rights in a formal statement but does not mention a Code of Conduct and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces suppliers in all of its supply chain. It does not appear to audit its suppliers.
Its animal rating is 'great'. The only animal product it uses is recycled leather.
DEADWOOD is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: May 2017

Title: Underprotection is a Copenhagen-based brand, founded in 2010 with a mission to create lingerie, loungewear and swimwear that will make you feel supported and comforted.
Description:
Underprotection's environment rating is 'great'. Its products are Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It monitors health and safety issues with an internal procedure. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep.
Underprotection is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: May 2020

Title: Bower is a British swimwear brand that offers luxury swimwear featuring bold prints and colours for the modern woman.
Description:
Bower's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. It uses recycled packaging. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Portugal and Italy, medium risk countries for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It states that its entire product range is vegan.
Bower is rated 'Good' overall.
Last Updated: September 2020

Title: LangerChen is a high-quality eco-outdoor brand for men and women that stands out through its timeless look and maximum functionality.
Description:
LangerChen's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. However its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'great'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It traces most of its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep.
LangerChen is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: PACT designs stylish, essential clothing that is comfortable and affordable.
Description:
PACT's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton. It encourages consumers to reduce their climate impact when using its products. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'good'. Its facilities are Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton certified and it is a member of Fair Trade USA. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses wool.
PACT is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: February 2020

Title: E.L.V. Denim take stocks of old discarded denim and transforms them into modern, sophisticated jeans.
Description:
E.L.V. Denim's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled fabrics. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the UK, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces all of its supply chain. It does not publically list names or addresses of any of its suppliers. There is no evidence it audits its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
E.L.V. Denim is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: February 2019

Title: nae is a Portuguese brand that creates vegan shoes, bags and accessories from organic and recycled materials.
Description:
nae's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Portugal, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It is listed by PETA as vegan.
nae is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Tri Colour Federation is an Australian based label that features premium, organic cotton denim garments.
Description:
Tri Colour Federation's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Australia, a low risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.<
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
Tri Colour Federation is rated 'Good' overall.
Last Updated: September 2020

Title: G Viteri produces ethical, handmade hats, bags and scarves in Ecuador using traditional methods and local materials.
Description:
G Viteri's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a proportion of eco-friendly materials including toquilla straw and a proportion of non eco-friendly materials including wool felt. It minimises the use of packaging and uses packaging from 100% post-consumer waste materials. It reduces waste at the final stage of production by upcycling and recycling offcuts. It reduces its carbon footprint by sourcing textiles from the same region it manufactures in and by hand-manufacturing its products. Its products that are made from eco-friendly materials limit the amount of chemicals used in production. However, there is no information about its policies on water usage and wastewater management.
Its labor rating is 'good'. It addresses workers’ rights in a formal statement but does not mention a Code of Conduct. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse but attempts to address those risks through operating according to Fair Trade principles, paying a fair wage and ensuring that its workers have access to healthy working conditions. It publicly lists the countries of its suppliers however does not share a complete list of suppliers. It is a social enterprise that exists to provide employment for people from marginalised or disadvantaged groups.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It uses wool without stating its sources. It does not use leather, angora, fur, down and exotic animal skin or hair.
G Viteri is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: February 2017

Title: Mary Young offers functional lingerie and loungewear that celebrates the natural shape and encourages body positivity.
Description:
Mary Young's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It minimises textile waste by using low-waste cutting techniques. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. It uses few eco-friendly materials.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Canada, a low risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. It traces most of its supply chain. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Mary Young is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: unspun is creating a denim world that reduces global carbon emissions by 1% through a zero-inventory and low waste process.
Description:
unspun's environment rating is 'great'. Its products are made to order to minimise textile waste. It implements initiatives to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from manufacturing. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in most of its products. It has implemented water reduction initiatives in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'good'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It has a project to improve wages in part of its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses a shrimp-based dye.
unspun is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Monki publishes detailed information about its suppliers and supply chain policies but it creates short-lived, fast fashion products.
Description:
Monki is owned by Hennes & Mauritz.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It has fast fashion traits such as on trend styles and regular new arrivals. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Almost none of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 71-80% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audit and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production, some information about the second and first stages of production and detailed information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes detailed information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain however there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses some policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but implementation is uncertain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Monki is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Rains is a Danish outerwear and waterproof clothing brand.
Description:
Rains's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. It uses sea freight shipping to reduce its climate impact. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It final stage of production is audited by Business Social Compliance Initiative Code of Conduct - BSCI.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It states that its entire product range is vegan.
Rains is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Womenswear brand creating staple items with timeless style.
Description:
Happy Haus's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton organic cotton. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in all of its products. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. It traces most of its supply chain. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain but does not specify what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses wool.
Happy Haus is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: October 2019

Title: Wolford has good policies to audit suppliers in its supply chain but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Wolford's environment rating is 'it's a start'. Most of its fabrics are Bluesign certified. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. There is no evidence it has set a greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. It manages the treatment and discharge of wastewater in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Most of its final stage of production is undertaken in the European Union, a low/medium risk region for labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It audits some of its supply chain but does not specify what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin or angora. It uses wool, exotic animal hair and silk.
Wolford is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: November 2019

Title: BeeKeeper Parade creates products that change the world, do no harm to the environment, and supports people and animals on this planet.
Description:
BeeKeeper Parade's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces all of its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
BeeKeeper Parade is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Nena & Co. creates artisan bags handmade by women in the Mayan highlands of Guatemala.
Description:
Nena & Co.'s environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including upcycled materials. It makes products by hand to reduce its climate impact. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'good'. It partners with artisans from Guatemala. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final and second stages of production. It is unclear whether it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather and wool.
Nena & Co. is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Sol Y Oro traces most of its supply chain but does not use eco-friendly materials
Description:
Sol Y Oro is owned by Hanesbrands Incorporated.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it recycles some off-cuts created during the manufacturing process. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions but does not do so for its entire supply chain and it does not use any widely accepted tools to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions. It has made a public commitment to reduce its carbon emissions by 40% by the year 2020 and it has taken meaningful action on meeting its carbon reduction target. It complies with a Restricted Substances List however it has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals from its supply chain. It measures and reports on water usage and wastewater management and publicly reports on targets.
Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It also traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain however it has very few worker empowerment initiatives. It received a good score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.
Sol Y Oro is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Triarchy's eco-friendly jeans, skirts and jackets are made using a Tencel cotton blend.
Description:
Triarchy's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled cotton. It uses a closed-loop system to reduce water use. It manages the treatment and discharge of wastewater in its supply chain. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. It sources its final stage of production from countries with high risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces all of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses recycled leather.
Triarchy is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: October 2019

Title: Sustainable vegan shoes that inspire compassion towards humanity, animals and the environment through creativity.
Description:
SUSI Studio's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. There is no evidence it minimises the use of solvent-based chemicals in its shoe production. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it does have a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It states that it's entire product range is vegan.
SUSI Studio is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

Title: Weekday publishes detailed information about its suppliers and supply chain policies but it creates short-lived, fast fashion products.
Description:
Weekday is owned by Hennes & Mauritz.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It has fast fashion traits such as on trend styles and regular new arrivals. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Almost none of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 71-80% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audit and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production, some information about the second and first stages of production and detailed information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes detailed information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain however there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses some policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but implementation is uncertain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, down, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Weekday is rated 'It's a start' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Anaak is a modern, timeless and feminine brand, empowering women and artisans around the world.
Description:
Anaak's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It makes products by hand to reduce its climate impact There is no evidence it minimises packaging. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in most of its products. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It visits its suppliers regularly.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin or angora. It uses wool and exotic animal hair.
Anaak is rated 'It's a start' overall.

Title: Copenhagen based brand, designing denim for nay occaision.
Description:
Blanche's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It encourages consumers to reduce their climate impact when using its products. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It has an internal grievance mechanism in its supply chain where reporting can be made anonymously. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, leather, exotic animal skin or angora. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep.

Title: Founded in 2009 after an extensive research process on natural materials, biodiversity and manual techniques, Flavia Aranha is a Brazilian design and fashion brand with the goal of supporting sustainability throughout its entire chain of production.
Description:
Flavia Aranha's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in most of its products. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with high risk of labour abuse. It traces most of its supply chain. It is unclear whether it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, fish leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.
