Title: Esprit publishes detailed information about its suppliers but is not taking adequate steps to minimise textile waste in its supply chain.
Description:
Esprit's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it has a policy to prevent deforestation in the supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Business Social Compliance Initiative Code of Conduct - BSCI including all of the final stage of production. It received a score of 61-70% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production, some information about the second and first stages of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in some of its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Esprit is rated 'It's a start' overall.

Title: Johnstons of Elgin has good policies to trace suppliers in its supply chain but it does not use eco-friendly materials.
Description:

Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the UK, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, exotic animal hair and silk. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.
Johnstons of Elgin is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Title: Tommy Hilfiger has made a public commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions but is not taking adequate steps to reduce textile waste in its supply chain.
Description:
Tommy Hilfiger is owned by PVH Group.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Some of its supply chain is certified by FLA Workplace Code of Conduct including all of the final stage of production. It received a score of 51-60% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain but there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with [Five Freedoms]. It uses leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.
Tommy Hilfiger is rated 'It's a start' overall.

Title: SeamsFriendly is a brand that designs clothes to work together, so you can wear them effortlessly, and contribute to a conscious lifestyle.

Its products are made to order to minimise textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.

Title: Prima Donna does not use any animal products but is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain
Description:

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it has a set a greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. It reuses its cardboard packaging. There is no evidence it has taken any meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'good'. All of its final stage of production is certified by Social Accountability International - SA8000. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles however it does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. It audits some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
. Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
Prima Donna is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Title: Katherine Hooker offers luxury British coats, jackets and dresses for everyday and special occasions such as weddings and events
Description:
Katherine Hooker's environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. There is no evidence it avoids hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. There is no evidence that it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'good'. . There is no evidence of a Code of Conduct however it minimises the risk of labour abuse as 100% of its final stage of production is located in low or medium risk countries for labour abuse. It ensures payment of a living wage payment across most of its supply chain and it traces most of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, exotic animal hair and silk. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin and angora.
Katherine Hooker is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Title: Level 99 Jeans is a Los Angeles based brand with a mission to create the perfect fitting women's jean.
Description:
Level 99 Jeans' environment rating is 'good'. It creates high-quality, long-lasting products. It uses a proportion of eco-friendly materials including Tencel, and a proportion of non eco-friendly materials including conventional cotton and modal. It offsets its carbon emissions through a valid carbon offset program. It has eliminated hazardous chemicals from its supply chain and implemented water reduction initiatives and policies.
Its labour rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its labour policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on its labour practices.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It uses leather without stating its sources. It does not use fur, wool, down and feathers, angora or exotic animal skin and hair.
Level 99 Jeans is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Better shoes for a better world
Description:
Swedish Hasbeens's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. It encourages consumers to reduce their climate impact when using its products. It uses vegetable tanned leather. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It does not disclose where all of its final stage of production occurs. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather.
Swedish Hasbeens is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2019

Title: Razzamatazz has good labour policies but does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Razzamatazz is owned by Pacific Brands.
Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces all or almost all of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It publicly lists all or a portion of its suppliers along with their addresses and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain. It has very few worker empowerment initiatives, but is making progress towards paying a living wage across some of its supply chain. It has signed the Bangladesh Building and Fire Safety Accord, is a member of the Ethical Trading Initiative - ETI and has pledged to not knowingly source Uzbek cotton for the manufacturing of any of its products.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.
Razzamatazz is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: May 2017

Title: Sleeper is an American brand that offers the world's first walking sleepwear so you can stay cool and comfortable all day.
Description:

There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the USA, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather, wool and silk.
Sleeper is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

Title: Naturalizer does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental and labor policies
Description:
Naturalizer is owned by Caleres Inc.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It covers most workers rights principles in its code of conduct. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It uses unannounced audits with new suppliers but only conducts follow up audits if faults occur. It pays a wage in accordance with local laws but not the definition of a living wage. It traces its suppliers in the final stage of production but does not publicly share a list of its suppliers.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, wool, feather, angora or exotic animal skin and hair. However it uses leather without stating its sources.
Naturalizer is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Johston of Elgin has good policies to trace suppliers in its supply chain.

Its labour rating is 'good'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Scotland, a medium risk country for labour abuse. It traces all of its supply chain. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It uses leather, exotic animal hair and silk.

Title: Slazenger does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Slazenger is owned by Designworks.
Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain. Title: Riders by Lee is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.

There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain including the final stage of production. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It does not disclose which animal products it uses..
Riders by Lee is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Missguided does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies.
Description:
Missguided's environment rating is 'very poor. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has fast fashion traits such as on trend styles and regular new arrivals. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the impacts of microplastics. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'very poor'. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining negotiations. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it ensures gender equality or empowerment in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur, down or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production.
Missguided is rated 'We avoid' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Le Pirol is a Nordic knitwear brand tailored for a modern, sustainable lifestyle.
Description:
Le Pirol's environment rating is 'great'. It is fully certified by Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint.Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'good'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Denmark, a low risk country for labour abuse. It traces most of its supply chain including all of final stage of production. It is unclear whether it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It audits most of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep.
Le Pirol is rated 'Great' overall.
Last Updated: September 2020

Title: Ucon Acrobatics strongly believes in the idea of innovative, functional and minimalistic products for creative consumers.
Description:
Ucon Acrobatics' environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It uses renewable energy in its direct operations to reduce its climate impact.. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'good'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It monitors health and safety issues by visiting all of its final stage of production suppliers. It ensures payment of a living wage in the final stage of production. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It is listed by PETA as vegan.
Ucon Acrobatics is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Will's Vegan Store produces animal and human friendly women's and men's footwear at affordable prices.
Description:

There is no evidence it minimises solvent-based chemicals in its shoe production. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the European Union, a low/medium risk region for labour abuse. It has a formal statement covering workers rights. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It is listed by PETA as vegan.
Will's Vegan Store is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: May 2019

Title: Sustainable and ethical fashion and design based on re-using and upcycling
Description:
Carmina Campus' environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled fabrics. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour rights. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces all of its supply chain. It participates in a robust program which empowers workers. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses fur and shearling. It uses recycled wool and recycled leather. It does not use down, angora or exotic animal skin or hair.
Carmina Campus is rated 'Good based on information from our own research.

Title: The first in vegan streetwear
Description:
ragwear's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including GOTS certified cotton and recycled materials and it creates high-quality, long-lasting products. There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. However its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse but attempts to address those risks by adopting the GOTS Code of Conduct. It ensures that a small proportion of its suppliers pay a living wage. It traces suppliers in the final stage of its supply chain and a small proportion of its supply chain is either independently audited or visited by the brand.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It uses 100% vegan materials.
ragwear is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It uses Fairtrade Cotton. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it does have a formal statement covering workers rights. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. It ensures payment of a living wage to some of its supply chain.

Title: Ahnu is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
Ahnu is owned by Deckers Outdoor Corporation (Deckers Brands)
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not have adequate policies and initiatives for resource management and disposal. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions, and has made a public commitment to reduce its Scope 3 emissions by 4 % during 2017. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. However it uses a REACH compliant Restricted Substances List, and 98% of its leather is sourced from Leather Working Group certified tanneries. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management for the majority of its supply chain.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It covers most workers' rights principles in its Code of Conduct but it is unclear if it applies to all of its supply chain. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces its manufacturing suppliers and it has publicly shared a complete list of its factories with addresses. It conducts audits once a year using third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing, and uses unannounced audits, however it does not audit all of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use wool, down and feathers, or shearling in its products, and it has policies prohibiting the use of fur, angora, and exotic animal skin. However it uses leather without stating its sources.
Ahnu is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Rimowa is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Rimowa is owned by LVMH.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. It complies with its own Restricted Substances List but there is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in medium risk countries for labour abuse. It received a score of 21-30% in the FTI. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather. It does not use fur, down, wool, exotic animal hair, angora or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.
Rimowa is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

Title: Timeless accessories handmade in London from recycled leather offcuts and plastic bottles.
Description:
BEEN London's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. It uses recycled packaging. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'good'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the UK, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It traces all of its supply chain. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses recycled leather.
BEEN London is rated 'Great' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2020

Title: Fine jewellery for women that evokes bohemian elegance and a sophisticated sensibility.
Description:
Natalie Perry's environment rating is 'good'. It ensures wastewater is treated and discharged properly in its supply chain. It makes products by hand to reduce its climate impact. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Most of its products are made to order to minimise waste.
Its labour rating is 'great'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the UK, a medium risk country for labour abuse. Most of its products are Fairtrade Certified Gold. It ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Natalie Perry is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: October 2019

Title: Norden creates stylish and functional performance outerwear from recycled plastic.
Description:
Norden's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its facilities are certified by Worldwide Responsible Accredited Production - WRAP. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It audits some of its suppliers including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It is listed by PETA as vegan.
Norden is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: December 2019

Title: RAEN is a classics-driven, boutique eyewear brand
Description:
Raen's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. There is no evidence it has taken any meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Raen is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2019

Title: Geox is not taking adequate steps to manage water use in its supply chain.
Description:
Geox's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. It uses renewable energy in its supply chain to reduce its climate impact. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It monitors health and safety issues with an internal procedure. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, wool, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather and down.
Geox is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: December 2019

Title: Chanel is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain.
Description:
Chanel's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Most of its final stage of production is undertaken in the European Union, a low/medium risk region for labour abuse. It received a score of 11-20% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes some information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not publish a list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose adequate policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather, wool, exotic animal hair and silk. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin or angora. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production.
Chanel is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Luxury outerwear ethically made in Canada with responsibly sourced natural fibers, sustainably harvested Canadian eiderdown and organic waxed cotton proofed in Scotland.
Description:
Olmsted Outerwear's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste in its supply chain. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Canada, a low risk country for labour abuse. It traces all of its supply chain. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply but not specify what percentage. It audits some of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, wool, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses down.
Olmsted Outerwear is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: December 2019

Title: Brelli offers luxury eco-friendly umbrellas that provide sun, rain, and wind protection
Description:
Brelli's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton and natural rubber to create high-quality, long-lasting products. Its products are 100% biodegradable in landfill environments. It produces the majority of its products by hand, reducing its carbon footprint. Its use of eco-friendly materials means it uses fewer chemicals and less water and wastewater in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its products are made by a small team in Thailand, a high risk country for labour abuse but it works to address those risks with a supplier code of conduct, addressing most workers rights principles. It pays a wage in accordance with local laws but not in definition of a living wage. It has publicly shared a complete list of suppliers but there is no evidence that it audits its supply chain.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.
Brelli is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2017

Title: Slow, sustainable luxury fashion, created by nomads turned artisans on the Tibetan Plateau.
Description:
Norlha's environment rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It makes products by hand to reduce its climate impact. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in all of its products. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'good'. It has a mission to improve social conditions in Nepal. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It traces all of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses yak wool.
Norlha is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

Title: A leather handbag and jacket collection based in NYC, inspired by motorcycle culture of the past and present, made sustainably in a family owned factory.
Description:
The Sway's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including upcycled materials. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. However its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its facilities are audited and reported through Sedex Members Ethical Trade Audit - SMETA Best Practice Guidance or Social Accountability International - SA8000. It monitors health and safety issues through an third party audit of its final stage of production suppliers. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, wool, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses recycled leather in most of its leather products.
The Sway is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Title: Make It Good apparel for women is a line of American made basics with artistically hand printed details
Description:
Make It Good's environment rating is 'good'. It creates high-quality, long-lasting products. It uses a proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton and recycled polyester and some non eco-friendly materials including conventional cotton and non-recycled polyester. It is taking steps to use 100% post consumer waste materials in its packaging. It reduces its carbon footprint by manufacturing close to its main retail outlets. It uses low impact and non-toxic dyes in its products. The use of water based inks also helps reduce its wastewater.
Its labour rating is 'good'. Its products are all made in-house by a small team including the owner of the business, but it does not provide enough information on the first and second stages of production.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.
Make It Good is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Henri Bendel does not use eco-friendly materials or ensure payment of a living wage across its supply chain
Description:
Henri Bendel is owned by L Brands.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not have adequate policies and initiatives for resource management and disposal. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions, but not for its entire supply chain and it does not use any widely accepted tools to guide measurement and reporting. It has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear time bound carbon reduction target. It has set a deadline for the elimination of hazardous chemicals by 2020 and it complies with a Restricted Substances List. It also has water reduction initiatives but has not set a specific reduction target. It participates in the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP).
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received a good score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. However it traces only one stage of its supply chain, it likely does not publicly list its suppliers and it does not guarantee that subcontracting does not occur in any of its supply chain. It audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period and it has minimal worker empowerment initiatives across its supply chain. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather without stating its sources. It does not use wool, down, fur, angora, exotic animal skin or hair.
Henri Bendel is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: August 2017

Description:
Nisolo's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. It uses chrome-free dyes in the leather tanning process There is no evidence it minimises packaging
Its labour rating is 'great'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It monitors health and safety issues with an internal procedure. It ensures payment of a living wage in the final stage of production. It traces most of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, wool, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather.
Nisolo is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: Saye is a footwear label that creates ecological sneakers using organic and recycled matierals, restoring forests and empowering local communities.
Description:
Saye's environment rating is 'good'. Its tanneries are audited by Leather Working Group. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton cotton. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'good'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Portugal, a medium risk country for labour abuse. It traces most of its supply chain. it is unclear whether it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather.
Saye is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: June 2020

Title: nativ basics is an eco-friendly underwear label designed for the everday woman.
Description:
nativ basics's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Tencel. There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. However its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain. It audits the final stage of production but does not state how often.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
nativ basics is rated 'Good' overall.
Last Updated: September 2020

Title: Parade is an American underwear brand that is working to re-write the American underwear story so you are left feeling soft, breathable and good for your body and the environment.
Description:

There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. However its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its factory is audited and reported through Sedex Members Ethical Trade Audit - SMETA Best Practice Guidance. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse . There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain. It audits its final stage of production but does not state how often.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials except for silk so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Parade is rated 'Good' overall.

Title: Save the Duck is not taking adequate steps to manage its greenhouse gas emissions.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all the Business Social Compliance Initiative Code of Conduct - BSCI principles. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces some of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It states that its entire product range is vegan.
Save the Duck is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Liska is one of Austria's oldest fur houses.
Description:
Liska's environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Its products are made to order to minimise textile waste. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Austria, a low risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses fur, leather, wool and exotic animal hair. It does not use down, exotic animal skin or angora.
Liska is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: WAMA is pioneering the Hemp Clothing industry with Premium Hemp Underwear.

Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
WAMA is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

Title: Studio Pia, luxury lingerie with a conscience. Designed by Pia Conaghan, and ethically crafted in the UK & Europe.

Title: High quality wholly-Australian made socks
Description:

Its labour rating is 'good'. Its final stage of production is certified by Ethical Clothing Australia. It traces all of its supply chain. Most of its supply chain is independently audited or visited by the brand.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin or angora. However it uses wool and exotic animal hair.

Title: Vegan footwear characterised by opulent materials and a subdued palette
Description:

Title: Bestform has some good labour policies but does not set clear targets for reducing carbon emissions or water usage
Description:
Bestform is owned by Fruit of the Loom Inc.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use eco-friendly materials, however it is taking steps to minimise waste and the use of packaging. It uses ISO 14064 and GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear time bound carbon reduction target. It is certified by Oeko-Tex Standard 100. It has water reduction initiatives but has not set any specific reduction targets.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report which looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It only audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain and it has very few worker empowerment initiatives. It has made little to no progress towards ensuring payment of a living wage across its supply chain.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.
Bestform is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: June 2017

Description:

There is no evidence it has taken any meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it implements wastewater management initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. Title: Holeproof has some strong labour policies but does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Holeproof is owned by Pacific Brands.
Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. There is insufficient relevant information on environmental sustainability to give this brand an appropriate environmental rating. Customers have a right to know how the products they buy impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces all or almost all of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It publicly lists all or a portion of its suppliers along with their addresses and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain. It has very few worker empowerment initiatives, but is making progress towards paying a living wage across some of its supply chain. It has signed the Bangladesh Building and Fire Safety Accord, is a member of the Ethical Trading Initiative - ETI and has pledged to not knowingly source Uzbek cotton for the manufacturing of any of its products.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, angora or leather but uses wool without specifying sources.
Holeproof is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: May 2017

Title: Nearly Nude has taken steps to address environmental issues and does not use any animal products
Description:
Nearly Nude is owned by Delta Galil Industries.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste in the manufacturing part of its supply chain. However it does not use eco-friendly materials. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions and it has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions per product by 5% by 2016. The majority of its products are Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. It implements water reduction initiatives and publicly reports on targets however this only covers in-house manufacturing.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a supplier Code of Conduct based on the FLA Workplace Code of Conduct. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It mentions paying a living wage and supplies an adequate definition but it does not assure payment of a living wage. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear as to what extent. As of 2014, it claimed to have audited 80% of its manufacturing suppliers for human rights screening but it does not appear to use unannounced audits.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labor scores only.
Nearly Nude is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: UGG is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
UGG is owned by Deckers Outdoor Corporation (Deckers Brands).
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not have adequate policies and initiatives for resource management and disposal. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions and has made a public commitment to reduce its Scope 3 emissions by 4 % during 2017. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. However it uses a REACH compliant Restricted Substances List and 98% of its leather is sourced from Leather Working Group certified tanneries. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management for the majority of its supply chain.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It covers most workers' rights principles in its Code of Conduct but it is unclear if it applies to all of its supply chain. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces its manufacturing suppliers and it has publicly shared a complete list of its factories with addresses. It conducts audits once a year using third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing and uses unannounced audits, however it does not audit all of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses wool from non-mulesed sheep and is a member of the Responsible Wool Standard. It does not use fur, angora, down, feathers or exotic animal skin. However it uses cashmere, shearling and leather without stating its sources.
UGG is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Clarks does not have strong environmental policies and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
Description:
Clarks is owned by C&J Clark International Ltd.
Its environmental rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials or have any strategies in place to reduce waste. It is taking steps to use 100% post-consumer waste materials in its packaging. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions, but has not set a target for direct or indirect emissions reduction. It has taken some steps to offset its emissions in the retail and operations section of its supply chain. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain, but it complies with a Restricted Substances List. Over 75% of its leather is sourced from at least bronze-certified Leather Working Group tanneries. There is no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It is a member of the Global Social Compliance Program (GSCP). It has a robust Supplier Code of Conduct. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risks of labour abuse, and it pays a wage in accordance with local laws but not in definition of a living wage. It traces suppliers in its manufacturing and inputs production sections of its supply chain but not in its first stage of production. It has listed the countries of its suppliers but it does not share a complete list. It audits once a year by third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing, but it does not use unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather and wool from unspecified sources. It does not use down, angora, shearling, fur, or exotic animal hair or skin.
Clarks is rated 'Not Good Enough', based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Camper is not taking adequate steps to manage water use in its supply chain.
Description:
Camper's environment rating is 'not good enough'. Its tanneries are audited by the Leather Working Group. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather and wool.
Camper is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

Title: Kayser does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Kayser is owned by Simon De Winter.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain, however it has minimal worker empowerment initiatives. It has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain. This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.
Kayser is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.
Last Updated: May 2017

Title: CASTAMIRA is a conscious luxury brand influenced by the 70's and 90's aesthetic, driven by a woman who embraces the quaintrelle spirit of luxury and play.
Description:
CASTAMIRA's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the USA, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
CASTAMIRA is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: July 2020

Title: Kustom does not provide sufficient information about its environmental policies.
Description:
Kustom is owned by Billabong.
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It has collaborated with Sea Shepherd to create an eco-friendly range using organic and recycled materials. However it does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. Very few of its facilities have worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It traces some of its supply chain including a proportion of the final stage of production. It audits some of its traced facilities. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the [ILO] principles however it has made little to no progress towards ensuring payment of a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use wool, fur, angora or exotic animal skin and fur. It uses leather.
Kustom is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: January 2019

Title: Giuseppe Zanotti uses fur and exotic animal products.
Description:
Giuseppe Zanotti's environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses fur, leather, exotic animal skin and silk. It does not use down or angora.
Giuseppe Zanotti is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: April 2020

Title: Dr. Martens is not taking adequate steps to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions.
Description:
Dr. Martens' environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. Its tanneries are audited by the Leather Working Group. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'very poor'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 0-10% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes zero or very limited information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not disclose any information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use down, exotic animal skin, angora or fur. There is no evidence it traces animal products to the first stage of production.
Dr. Martens is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: August 2020

Title: Jockey does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
Description:
Jockey’s environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It is Worldwide Responsible Accredited Production - WRAP certified and has a robust Supplier Code of Conduct. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risks of labor abuse and there is no evidence that it provides a living wage for its workers. It does not adequately trace suppliers in its supply chain or publicly share a list of its suppliers. It mentions auditing but it is unclear how often and which part of the supply chain it audits and it does not appear to use unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use leather, fur, angora, shearling, down or exotic skins or hairs. However it uses wool without stating its sources.
Jockey is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Cole Haan does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies.
Description:
Cole Haan is owned by Apex partners .
Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it investigates and reports on safety incidents. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It has a Code of Conduct that covers some of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It uses leather and wool.
Cole Haan is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: May 2020

Title: Birkenstock is not taking adequate steps to manage its greenhouse gas emissions.
Description:
Birkenstock's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions. It uses water-based glues to minimise the use of solvent-based chemicals in its shoe production. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Its final stage of production is mostly undertaken in the European Union, a low/medium risk region for labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather and wool. It does not use fur, down, angora, exotic animal skin or hair. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production.
Birkenstock is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
Last Updated: September 2020

Title: Planet friendly and luxury swimwear brand.
Description:
Miska Paris' environment rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. Its products are Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. There is no evidence it implements wastewater management initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final and second stages of production. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.

Title: Wacoal does not communicate sufficient information about its labor policies
Description:
Wacoal is owned by Wacoal Holdings.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not have adequate policies and initiatives for resource management and disposal. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions and has made a public commitment to reduce its carbon emissions by 25% by the year 2020. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals or reduce water usage in its supply chain.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. A large percentage of products are manufactured in-house and it addresses some workers' rights in a formal statement but does not mention a Code of Conduct. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its labor policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on its labor practices.
This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labor scores only.
Wacoal is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Victoria's Secret is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
Description:
Victoria's Secret is owned by L Brands.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the impacts of microplastics. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. It has set a deadline to eliminate hazardous chemicals by 2020 but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 21-30% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose adequate policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials except for silk so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Victoria's Secret is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

Very few of its facilities have worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It audits some of its traced facilities. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO principles however it has made little progress in ensuring payment of a living wage.
Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair. However it uses wool and leather.

Title: allsisters is a luxury generation brand making eco-friendly and sustainable swimwear
Description:
allSisters' environment rating is 'great'. Its products are certified by OEKO-TEX Made in Green. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It manufactures locally to reduce its carbon footprint.
Its labour rating is 'good'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Spain, a medium risk country for labour abuse. It traces all of its supply chain. It is unclear whether it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
allSisters is rated 'Great' based on information from our own research.

Title: Ethically produced luxury towels, robes, linen and more.
Description:
The Madison Collection's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified organic cotton. It uses renewable energy in its supply chain to reduce its climate impact. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.
Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. It ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.
The Madison Collection is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: November 2019

Title: Karen Neuburger has taken steps to address environmental issues and does not use any animal products
Description:
Karen Neuburger is owned by Delta Galil Industries.
Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste in the manufacturing part of its supply chain. However it does not use eco-friendly materials. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions and it made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions per product by 5% by 2016. The majority of its products are Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. It implements water reduction initiatives and publicly reports on targets however this only covers in-house manufacturing.
Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a supplier Code of Conduct based on the FLA Workplace Code of Conduct. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It mentions paying a living wage and supplies an adequate definition but it does not assure payment of a living wage. It traces suppliers in its supply chain, although it is unclear as to what extent. As of 2014, it claimed to have audited 80% of its manufacturing suppliers for human rights screening but it does not appear to use unannounced audits.
Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.
Karen Neuburger is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.
Last Updated: March 2017

Title: Conscious Swimwear is a Portuguese premium swimwear brand that creates collections from ocean plastic and waste.
Description:

Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in Portugal, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain. It visits its suppliers regularly.
This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.
Conscious Swimwear is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

Description:

There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. Its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals and water used in production.
Its labour rating is 'good'. All factories are certified by GOTS. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs however it ensures payment of a living wage across its supply chain.
Its animal rating is 'good'. There is no evidence that it uses animal products but does not mention being vegan.
Vigga is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

Title: GEORGE is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain

Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It is a member of the Ethical Trading Initiative - ETI and has adopted the ETI base code. It has a project to improve wages in a part of its supply chain.

Title: Dorothy Perkins is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain

It has set a greenhouse gas emissions target but it does not specify whether it relates to its direct operations or its supply chain. There is no evidence that it has taken any meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence that it implements water reduction initiatives.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence that it has any worker empowerment initiatives. It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. Title: TK Maxx uses animal products including exotic animals
Description:
TK Maxx is owned by The TJX Companies, Inc.
Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It is fully certified by the Carbon Trust. It has fast fashion traits such as on trend styles and regular new arrivals. It has set an intensity target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations by 30% but it has not set a target covering any of its supply chain. There is no evidence that it has taken any meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence of a current water target or goal.
Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence that it investigates and reports on safety incidents. It does not mention payment of a living wage. There is no evidence of listing names or addresses for any of its suppliers. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state which part and what percentage.
Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, exotic animal hair and silk. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin and angora.
TK Maxx is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.
